PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.

Your humble petitioners pray that the Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) or his advisers have any further comments or responses to make in relation to the questions which were raised yesterday by Senator Patterson and Senator Walters and the points which were raised by me in relation to the independent peer review organisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot add to the information that I supplied to the Committee last evening on the questions that were raised by the honourable senators referred to by Senator Puplick. From the Government point of view, we have been exhaustive in putting forward answers as best we can to the questions on discrimination and whether or not what is being done in Australia is harsher than what is being done elsewhere. I think we have put that to rest. I have replied in some detail to the question concerning the independent peer review and wait for the completion of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is necessary for me to answer in some more detail another question that was raised last night-the question of appeals by general practitioners, if they feel the need to do so, against the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners' assessments. I would like to take a minute to deal comprehensively with that matter, which takes my fancy as something worthy of putting down on the record in some detail. The first point that I make is that the Health Insurance Commission puts general practitioners on the register based on decisions taken by the college-that is, if the college is prepared to certificate them as eligible-and takes them off either at the request of a general practitioner or on a notice from the college for whatever specified reason. There is a series of specified reasons. The categories are set out in the Act and I will not go through them. The decisions of the Health Insurance Commission are appealable, if that be the right word, under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. On page 8 of its report, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee states:

In view of the major role played in the process by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, the Committee does not regard it as necessary that the general manager's discretion should be subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Committee regards the review of the legality of the discretion pursuant to the Administrative Decisions Judicial Review Act 1977 as sufficient safeguard in these circumstances.

If that be the line of approach for the Health Insurance Commission, it throws some responsibility on the shoulders of the college. The first element in a consideration of what the college's responsibilities might be is whether this Government can impose on the college a set of appeal provisions. Our legal advisers have it that there is doubtful legality as to whether we as a government can compel an independent organisation like the college to institute an appeals structure or set-up of the sort that we might wish to impose or which those opposite might think we should impose. I have left aside the question of the desirability of the Government's intervening in the proceedings of an organisation like the college, but it is a relevant question. I do not shy away from it. Nonetheless, the question of our legal ability to do that is debatable.

What do we now do? The college itself has agreed-it is set out in the discussion document to which I referred last night-that a mechanism will be developed to allow medical practitioners to appeal against exclusion or removal from the register. Someone as incisive and discriminating as Senator Peter Baume may well say that as a general undertaking taken at face that is fair enough, but that it is not good enough in that it does not spell out what the proceedings might be. If that were raised, I would say that it is absolutely right that those proceedings are not spelt out. How should we therefore answer that concern? I am advised that had this provision been passed last night or today in the time between the carriage of these Bills and their obtaining royal assent, the college would have been in a position to have instituted an appeals structure with the terms of that structure clear, with the procedures of the mechanisms clear and with the appointment of an arbitrator to head up the structure. It would be an independent appeal mechanism so that the problem identified last night by Senator Peter Baume of Caesar appealing to Caesar over a decision made by Caesar would not exist. The college would set it up, but it would stand aside from the college and would thus be an independent appeal mechanism.

Given the body language of those opposite, I presume I am right in anticipating that the next line of objection will concern the question of why that mechanism cannot be seen at this stage. At this point, this chamber has decided to refer all this to an inquiry of a Senate select committee. The evidence will be presented to the Senate select committee so that it can analyse it and check whether the appeal mechanism is satisfactory. Had we been in a position of proceeding with this Bill today, the Government would have become satisfied, given our discussions with the college, that the mechanism and its efficacy were proper. I say that in this debate quite unabashedly. As a government we would be concerned to see that that was so.

There is a fine line between compulsion and discussion and persuasion. We believe by exercising discussion and persuasion that the reservoir of goodwill between the Government and the college, if this question were ever in doubt, would have made it possible to resolve any doubt. I am therefore not able to put to the Senate this morning what the appeal structure and the procedures would be and who the independent arbitrator would be. That is a matter which can come before the Committee and be looked at by it.

It would seem to me that one option for the Committee would be to endorse the independent structure that the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners would set up. That is an option we would prefer. It has another option: to interpose between the college and the Health Insurance Commission some other form of structure. As a government we have shied clear of interfering in the internal affairs of the college. But if the Senate chose to do that it would be possible to contemplate the setting up of an independent structure which would sit between the college and the Health Insurance Commission.

If someone, having exhausted his appeal rights within the college, was dissatisfied with a decision from the college, he could theoretically appeal to this structure that we would put in place and have his appeal dealt with in that way. That is another possibility. The reason why we have not gone down that course is that we thought in all of the circumstances that it was proper to proceed in common accord with the college to resolve these matters. We believe that would have produced the results which would have resolved these matters. It is not just a question of hope; it is also a question of belief that we would have got there. I hope that answers those questions, in particular the ones about appeals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Resources for his explanation. I understand that basically what he is saying is that there remains a right of appeal under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act on questions of law, but on questions of merit we will have to wait for some body to be devised by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners in consultation with the Government for these matters to be addressed. May I say a couple of things about that. Firstly, it just reinforces the value of having this matter before a Senate committee. The college undoubtedly will want to present to the Senate committee its precise mechanism. Undoubtedly, should it fail to do so, the committee will be entitled to draw conclusions from that. Undoubtedly the college will be able to appear before the committee and indicate to it what it has proposed or what it will be proposing and the committee will be able to make some judgment on that. Nevertheless it does not entirely answer the questions about avenues of appeal.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook is a little too used to dealing with Caesar. It is not a question of Caesar appealing to Caesar. What the Opposition is concerned about is not Caesar's rights of appeal but the rights of Civitas Romani. Perhaps if the Minister and the Government spent a little less time looking after Caesar and a little more time looking after the citizenry they would not be in the mess they are in at the moment.

The questions of the mechanism are mentioned in the document Raising the Standard, a copy of which was provided formally to us this morning. One is always grateful for small mercies, even indeed for late mercies, as far as these things are concerned. That document simply says in part:
A mechanism will be developed to allow medical practitioners to appeal against exclusion or removal from the register.
We have heard the Minister's explanation on that matter. Obviously, this will now be a matter for the Senate Committee to take further.
I have one final question relating to this section. In the same document, relating to another part of the audit function in this scheme, it is stated on page 3:
Dr Blewett and Dr Gates-
the Dr Gates who has signed this agreement on behalf of the college-

said that monitoring of and auditing the use of the new content-based items would be carried out by a peer review body independent of Government and the RACGP, but with the full support of the college.

I ask the Minister: Is that the Independent Peer Review Organisation (IPRO)? If it is, how can the Minister say that that body will be `independent of government and the RACGP' when that body is to be composed, apparently, of three members nominated by the college, a nominee from a separate appropriate medical organisation chosen by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) in consultation with the college, a nominee of the Department of Community Services and Health and a nominee of the Health Insurance Commission? What is the definition of the term `independent of government and the college' when the college nominates three persons and has a hand in nominating a fourth? Presumably, the Minister who has responsibility for the Department and the Commission will have a hand in the nomination of the other members. Firstly, can the Minister confirm that the so-called independent body is the IPRO? Secondly, can he explain to us the way in which he has now constituted a new definition of the term `independent'?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night Senator Coulter made a telling observation which went along the lines that all of these matters are going to a Senate select committee where they can be inquired into, fossicked about with and held up to the light to see whether they are transparent. The Senate Committee will then deliberate and in due course bring down a report. We are here starting the forensic research that the Committee should rightfully do. Therefore, I think I should take some elements of Senator Puplick's question on notice. The Minister for Community Services and Health may then be able to reply to them.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, let us not make this mistake when we talk about independent committees. Organisations may well-and rightfully should, since they are the organisations embracing the particular professional qualifications and skills required-nominate individuals to sit on committees. Once they do that and a committee is constituted there is a clear distinction between a representative and a nominee, someone who is then able to sit independently. The Government is seeking for this body not a representative to impose a policy but someone with the necessary qualifications, adjudged by the relevant organisation, to be independent of it and exercise that independence in the Peer Review Organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I love the Minister's fine line between a nominee and a representative. I do not think many people would agree with his fine line of distinction. I wish to bring up another matter relating to the same clause. Under proposed new section 3h the Minister has the power to appoint another body instead of the college. Can the Minister give me some idea as to the thinking of the Government regarding the likelihood of the appointment of such a body? What sort of body is in the thinking of those who drafted the legislation?

—Last night I asked four questions on notice, of which the Minister was not able to answer the first two, about the number of consultations that trainees in the family medicine program experienced or had the opportunity to undertake. Would the Department be able to provide that information in time for the Committee to look at it and be able to assess the experience students have in traineeships? It would be preferable to have the information in time for the Senate Select Committee rather than in three months time. Would the Minister guarantee that we can have that information for the Select Committee?

—We will supply that information provided that we can do it without infringing the secrecy provisions of the Health Insurance Commission Act. We can give the honourable senator an undertaking to give it our best shot. It would be desirable to do so.

—Is the Minister going to answer the question that I put to him? We have a clause that says that the Minister may determine whether another body can take over the powers of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, yet the Government is not prepared to give us its reasons for including this provision in the legislation. What type of body is the Government thinking of? Is the Minister refusing to answer the question?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can take it that the Minister-indicated by his silence-refuses to answer the question. We note that. We are also intrigued with his answer to Senator Patterson's question. He said that the Senate committee will be provided with information provided it does not breach the secrecy provisions of the Health Insurance Commission Act. If that principle is applied, it will be the first occasion that this Government has ever decided to take the secrecy provisions of the Health Insurance Commission Act seriously. It is interesting that the Government is prepared to say that it will invoke them to withhold information if possible from Senator Patterson, the Senate and the Senate committee, but that it will not do anything to ensure that it does not make use of that information in the public debate in the scandalous way in which it has in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude my remarks on clause 10 by noting that the Minister has clearly affirmed that the Independent Peer Review Organisation is the body referred to in the joint statement by Dr Blewett and Dr Gates about the independent review body. I am sure that once general practitioners have had a chance to see exactly what are the operating principles of this organisation, they will be better placed to see the extent to which the Government and the college are pulling the wool over their eyes. In terms of independent organisations, if we are to have such bodies, I hope in some respects that they have a slightly better track record in observing the law and in observing principles of equity and natural justice than the Government's advisory bodies have had to date.

Part of this legislation establishes a new pathology schedule because the Federal Court of Australia decided that the previous body, the Pathology Services Advisory Committee, was incapable or had failed in its statutory duty to observe the requirements of the Act when setting pathology tables. We have seen today a report from the Federal Court of Australia overturning the determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. The report said that the attempts to reduce pharmacy fees were unreasonable, contrary to the principles of natural justice, and so unreasonable that no reasonable person could have come to that determination. So the Government's track record in setting up these bodies, which are designed to do its dirty work for it in terms of cost cutting, has been, by and large, set at nought by the courts of Australia, which have once again demonstrated that they are far more solicitous of the rights of ordinary citizens and of professionals in this country than the Government has ever attempted to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind Senator Cook that I am asking for general statistics which show the minimum, maximum and average number of services provided to trainees in an average sample of general practitioner trainees and, if possible, the standard deviation which would give us some idea of the range of services provided. I do not think that that would breach any privacy Act. I already have a copy of that sort of information obtained under freedom of information legislation. I think it would be more appropriate to have official data from the Department of Community Services and Health to enable the Senate Select Committee to make some sort of objective judgment about the range of experiences that a trainee has. I hope that the Department will stretch itself to provide that information.

—Can I establish for the record whether the Minister has nothing else to say as a matter of policy concerning this legislation, or whether he is simply unwilling to give the information and needs more time in order to do so? If it is the latter, we will be perfectly happy to facilitate his consideration of these matters by reporting progress and waiting for him to get some information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that I have answered the questions that have been put to me as fully and reasonably as can be expected on this occasion. However, I do note that the Opposition is engaging in some sort of facile attempt to conduct an inquiry when, against the Government's will, this chamber has decided that there shall be an inquiry by a Senate select committee. SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators opposite are clearly trying to massage into the consciousness of Australians that there is something grievously wrong with the Government's handling of the health portfolio. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the Minister refuses to answer my question about the type of body that is to be established. Is it because he does not know? Limitation of effect

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support the amendment moved by Senator Coulter, which effectively provides a sunset clause on the Government's bandaid operations in relation to health reinsurance arrangements in this country. As I said yesterday, the Government's proposals in this legislation will do nothing to achieve long term improvements in the private health insurance system. They will do nothing to protect the insured aged from further increases in contribution rates. Indeed, they are more likely to make the system chronically worse by driving good risks out of the private health insurance system. Who can blame the young and the healthy for looking at their personal finances when faced with yet another rise and future rises in health fund contribution rates and deciding that they will have to opt out because they are no longer willing to pay that cost on top of the 1.25 per cent Medicare levy which the Government is ripping out of their taxable income without any relief and without their being able to do anything about it?

SPEECH.PARA: Between September 1983 and March 1989 the proportion of the population covered by private health insurance had fallen from something like 62.7 per cent to 46.2 per cent, meaning that-taking into account that drop in insured numbers and adding population growth-there are now 2.751 million more Australians dependent on Medicare than there were in September 1983. As I said yesterday, for every one per cent drop in those privately insured, the public sector ends up having to bear an additional cost of between $80m and $90m. The arrangements proposed, including the quick fix $20m sudden contribution, like some death-bed repentance, to the reinsurance pool, are not going to solve this particular problem.

Senator Coulter, quite rightly, makes the point that there has been some toing and froing on the determination of how these provisions should be dealt with. We have indicated that that $20m quick fix was quite unreasonable. After all, in the last five years the Government has withdrawn something like $430m in assistance from those people who have had and maintained private health insurance, an amount equivalent to something like $2.74 per contributor per week. This $20m reinsurance contribution over the next 18 months will equal about 8c per contributor per week. I think that is a clear indication of the way in which the Government has proceeded in this matter.

The original view that these provisions should be opposed led to a situation in which the Government and some of its political supporters mounted a campaign which can only be described as outrageous, designed to put fear into the sick and the elderly; to indicate to them that the failure of the Senate to pass this legislation would somehow lead to real problems for them as individuals, prejudice their health care and prejudice their quality of life. That dishonest and disreputable campaign, using the aged and the sick for these political purposes, was not one of the more edifying spectacles of public policy conducted in the last couple of years.

I appreciate that concerns are held by people in the private insurance sector about this sunset clause, but the fact that somebody decides to get into bed with the Government does not guarantee a peaceful night's sleep. The Government is not going to get a simple blank cheque for an endless arrangement without proper review. I make it quite clear that the Opposition parties are absolutely committed not only to achieving better private health care arrangements in Australia but also to facilitating the entry of a greater number of people into private health insurance arrangements. We want to see more people privately insured. When we have the opportunity shortly to release our health and health insurance policies, that will be quite evident.

Senator Coulter has rightly pointed out that a large number of these matters will now be the subject of inquiry by the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance. That will report, in terms of the timetable which was laid down the other day, if my memory serves me correctly, by the first sitting day of March 1990. Senator Coulter then said, speaking to his amendment, that between March 1990 and 30 June 1990 the Government will have to consider the advice and recommendations of that Committee and determine whether it wishes the system simply to lapse, which would be the effect of this amendment, or whether it wishes to relegislate in precisely the same form, in which case it will have to come back to the Parliament, or relegislate in some amended form on the basis of the evidence and advice that the Senate Select Committee will give as a result of its inquiry.

I think that is a perfectly proper way to proceed. We do not believe that the system proposed is a satisfactory one. The Government has now been given, in effect, a 12-month period to look quite closely at what it sees as the ongoing issues to be resolved in terms of health insurance and health care arrangements. It will then be the responsibility of the Government to determine whether it will relegislate or simply allow the system to pass out of existence. Needless to say, should the Government have the courage to call a general election prior to that date, the Opposition parties will be in a position to put in place our own health policies as far as this matter is concerned. It is perfectly proper that we should not consider ourselves bound on an ongoing basis by the unsatisfactory arrangements which the Government has made and is now putting into legislative form in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. It is for those purposes that we support the amendment moved by Senator Coulter. It will force the Government to face up to fundamental questions rather than to continue with its bandaid approach, which has been the hallmark of its approach to questions of health insurance and reinsurance arrangements in the last 12 months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recognise that in this chamber a coalition of parties is ranged against the Government. The Liberal Party of Australia, since we came to government in 1983, has had five shadow Ministers for community services and health and six different policies, some of which it could not make add up. The Liberal Party is opposed to us. Then, unabashedly and unashamedly, there is the National Party of Australia. It is opposed to us, and the less said about that the better. What I cannot understand is why the Australian Democrats are opposed to us, but they are. With this conjunction of opposition, I have to recognise that the Government does not have the numbers and is likely therefore to lose. But before we go down, if that be our fate, let me address some remarks to the Democrats as to why I think they ought, prior to casting their votes, to think again about this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: In this chamber, last night and today, the Democrats have taken from the Government important amendments that it wanted to put through for general practitioners and health reinsurance. The Democrats have sent those proposals to a committee to inquire into them. Thus the reforms the Government wanted to make have been delayed. Thus the outcome for the future for general practitioners and health reinsurance is uncertain. The organisations which have induced this uncertainty, legislatively and in the wider community, are not the Government but those who have voted together to bring about this result. Let me go to the administrative undesirables before I go to the policy undesirables. The first administrative undesirable is that the report of the select committee will be due by 1 March. Honourable senators opposite expect us to have developed a response to that report and to have consulted widely. In the last division we were accused of not consulting widely enough. The Democrats have never been in government and may never be in government, but I put to the Senate that that is an unreasonable imposition to place on government and because of its tight boundaries on time, it imposes on the whole of the community a considerable anxiety as to the future of health matters and reinsurance. The second objection I ask the Democrats to consider goes to the very nature of this chamber. By seeking a sunset provision like this, this chamber can be said to be seeking to be the primary legislative body. This chamber is a review chamber. It is not where the Government is formed; it is where legislation proposed by the Government is considered, reviewed and sent back for further consideration by the Government. The proposed amendment tries to harness this chamber as the primary legislative source and the one which will control the fate of legislation. I think that is unreasonable. The Senate may review these provisions, by all means, but it should not put the Government in a position in which it cannot govern. I raise that as a principled objection.

But let me go to the practical effect. What are the policy objections? In this legislation we have concentrated on delivering to the health insurance industry long and strong signals that enable the industry to act in a stable and ongoing way to provide continuity and to be able to work its tables out so that people know what the payments will be and what they will be into the future. This sunset provision removes that long term security and stability of the industry and plunges it into a position in which it can work its actuarial calculations only for one year, because that is the only period for which it has any certainty. After the year is up, who knows what will happen? Who knows how the industry can spin its wheels and calculate its figures to see what the new set of fees will be? That is an unreasonable thing to impose not only for the health insurance industry but for those who are consumers and have voluntarily decided to take out extra health insurance. This anxiety has been raised by pensioner organisations, by the voluntary health funds themselves on behalf of pensioners and by the wider constituency of those health funds.

The Democrats should consider the sunset provision in view of the fact that instability and constant anxiety and capriciousness is bad government-or at least the Liberals and the Nationals should consider the provision in that light. They should deliver some stability and certainty to the industry so that it can go ahead and make its calculations. If there is a need later, after the inquiry and its report, to modify at the margin, we can do so; but not on a basis that they are chopped off after one year and the whole thing is plunged into some sort of chaos.

If this amendment is carried and goes back to the House of Representatives, the Government will seek to reject it there and the legislation will have to come back here again. I do not say that lightly. It is a significant problem. The Government will not resile from its position. We will then be required to have another debate on this issue. I say those things to the Democrats and ask them, before proceeding on this issue, finally to reconsider some of those principles and make a decision in the interests of the industry, the wider community and some degree of stability.

Let me conclude by referring to some of Senator Puplick's remarks. I find his remark that the Liberal Party is about better health care very odd indeed. That may well be the rhetoric the Liberal Party engages in. We just had a burst of it a minute ago. That is what members of the Liberal Party say, but political organisations are judged not so much by what they say but by what they do. What was the record of the Liberal Party during the Fraser years? Can anyone remember how many times Medibank, as it was then, was changed, the health arrangements were altered, people were forced into private health insurance that led, finally, to crippling burdens, and where the sense of equity that we have introduced in Medicare was removed from the community? Can we remember back in those days?

The Liberal Party says it wants better private health care. What is that code for? It is code for Andrew Peacock saying, `Yes, there is a need in the wider economy to cut government expenditure further'. He said this many times in the lead-up to his leadership challenge, but very little since his election because he wants to fudge and cloud this issue. Where will he cut expenditure? In set-piece speeches in which he has had a considered view to put-so he is not being doorstopped; he has not had a question popped at him out of the blue and made a false response-he has said that he will find cuts in the Medicare and health care areas, in the welfare area. That means that more and more of the burden of health costs go on to the shoulders of the wider community. Because the distribution of incomes is unequal, but the imposition of the burden will be equal, those who are least able to afford it will pay most and they will be put in real jeopardy. That is the Liberal Party's position. Why would a Labor Government, committed to social equity, connive to bring about that result? We will not do so. We will not be put in a position in which we shift the cost back on to those who can least afford it.

Senator Puplick made the quite remarkable argument that he is concerned about the anxiety that has been created among less fortunate people in the community. That is a very patronising view, because it assumes absolutely that the pensioner organisations do not have a true perception of their self- interest, that the pensioner organisations that have been lobbying Senator Puplick, this Government and, I believe, the Australian Democrats do not know what they are lobbying the parties about. Of course, they know. Of course, they know the risk to their constituents that those sorts of changes, if brought about, would create.

Senator Puplick's argument also presupposes that the voluntary health insurance organisations do not know what is in their real interest. He concluded by saying that he would not be bound by the ongoing values of the Labor Party. That may also be code for saying that the Opposition does not support the community rating principle. The Government wants to see the community rating principle continue. That principle requires a brief explanation. Because older people are more likely to get sick and require medical attention more often, some people are lobbying for the amount they pay for health insurance to be related to the frequency with which they go to hospital and for the cost of insurance not to be calculated right across the population, including all types of people, ages and income groups who take up private health insurance. That would mean that younger, fitter people would pay less while older people, prone to ill health, would pay more. There is a strong lobby to turn over the community rating principle and Senator Puplick has said that he does not want to be bound by the ongoing values of the Government. Why does he not come out and clearly say that he does not want the community rating principle enshrined, because that is what he is saying?

I can understand why someone who takes an administrative or a rationally logical and narrow approach-such as an Australian Democrat-would move a sunset provision like this. But to do so narrowly is to do so blinkeredly and to do so blinkeredly, without taking account of the wider landscape and the impact that a blinkered decision would have on that wider landscape, is bad policy, bad decision-making and just plain wrong. Therefore, I ask the three parties to reconsider their support for this amendment; I ask that it be defeated.
