DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989DEFENCE SERVICE HOMES AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10, 23 and 25 May, on motions by Senators Robert Ray and Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to two of the Bills in this package, the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. There are some important points that need to be made for the purposes of assessing the Government's performance in this area. The Bills implement the 12 April economic statement and deal specifically with family payments-namely, family allowances and the family allowance supplement, rental assistance and indexation of pensions, benefits and family payments. The changes announced in the 12 April economic statement were welcomed by the Opposition in many ways but they only went a small way towards redressing the severe losses that Australian families have suffered at the hands of this Hawke Government since it has been in office. But it has put the plight of families right back on the agenda. That has been largely at the instigation of the Opposition, the coalition parties, which through the document Future Directions has put great stress on families and the important role they play within the community. They are the very fabric of our society.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition has always been aware of the importance of the family in Australian society. We recognise the changing needs of families in all their various configurations. It is important to note also that the family allowance was a Fraser Government initiative. It is good that this Government has reflected in its own policies the importance of this Fraser initiative. But simple financial assistance at the margin can never solve the problems that we face in the important area of obtaining social justice. The Government has failed in all its initiatives to meet its desired `fair go for all' policy. It is only under a coalition Government that we will see that fair go for all Australians established. It is only now that the Government, thanks to the Opposition, has been dragged reluctantly, if all too late, into recognition of the fact that Australian families are bleeding and have been haemorrhaging since the Labor Party has occupied the government bench.

For a family with a single average weekly income, a dependent spouse and two dependent children the real standard of living in terms of disposable income rose between 1977 and 1982. In recent years real disposable income has fallen to a critical degree. The tax cuts announced by Mr Keating on 12 April will mean slightly higher living standards for average families in 1989 compared with last year, but will leave them considerably below their real standard of living in 1982 and even 1977. The tax cuts, totalling $4.9 billion, are considerably less than the $10 billion the Government has collected in bracket creep alone, not to mention all the new taxes over the last several years including the soon to be debated superannuation taxes. Australia's debt has risen; everyone is concerned and aware of the monumental figures. What does this mean to Mr and Mrs Average Australia? There are slightly more broken down figures showing that, for example, in 1985 34c of every export dollar earned was paid in overseas commitments; now the first 63c in every dollar we earn is owed to the rest of the world.

A study carried out by the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research at the University of Melbourne has demonstrated that 13 per cent of income units were in poverty in 1986 compared with 10.5 per cent only four years earlier. Today 2.6 million households-one in every eight-live in poverty. This is hardly a record of which this Government can be proud.

This package of Bills is aimed at giving support to families. We applaud and approve of that objective. But the most appalling fact is that about 800,000 children are living in poverty. The tragedy of child poverty has become a major issue in both social and political debate. These young Australians have been the real victims of the plummeting living standards over which this Government has presided for the past six years. We are told by the Brotherhood of St Laurence that, compared with other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, with the exception of the United States of America, we have the highest child poverty rate.

Mr Hawke's claim that the Government has eradicated child poverty is a scandalous statement because it engenders a very real danger of complacency. Yet, the Government claims that it has eradicated child poverty in accordance with its much vaunted claim in 1987 that there would be no child poverty by 1990. The introduction of the family allowance supplement has assisted approximately only 30 per cent of these 800,000 children. The Social Welfare Research Centre at the University of New South Wales estimates that, even after housing costs are paid and other ameliorating influences are taken into account, some 400,000 children will remain in poverty. It is an appalling record for a country such as ours. Child poverty has become endemic to Australian society and simply will not be remedied by a limited income support system. It is too little and it is too late. We have to address other areas such as housing, employment, and education. Overall, we have to address the entire economic situation.

People need a roof over their heads. They need to be warm in winter. Housing poverty in Australia is concentrated particularly among families with dependent children-both couples and sole parents-and those in the rental market are most severely affected. Despite the housing crisis and the existence of 195,000 families on the public housing waiting lists around Australia, the Government took no action to increase housing assistance in its economic statement, except for a meagre rental allowance increase. As I said the improvements which these Bills will bring about in terms of the family allowance supplement are to be commended. But there is no way that the assistance package can tackle the enormous rent blow-outs that exist in Sydney and Melbourne alone. That, together with the average mortgage repayment which has increased by some $500 a month since 1983, means that people are finding it more difficult to obtain housing. Research done by the Salvation Army estimates that some four million families in Australia are affected by this problem. It is not just a matter of families tightening their belts a little; it is a question of making life extraordinarily difficult for them as they try to keep a roof over their heads. Major Elizabeth Johnson of the Salvation Army said:

Housing is the biggest social problem in our community. It is not just the case of people not owning their own homes-it is the case of people not having any home-it is the case of people being exploited-it is the case of people living in poor conditions-it is the case of people living in poverty after paying housing costs.

As I said, there are now 195,000 families waiting for public housing in Australia. The statistics on housing provided by the Australian Council of Social Service highlight the point. The waiting periods for public housing are extending. Twenty per cent of home purchasers are paying more than 30 per cent of their income in home repayments. Forty per cent of private renters pay more than 30 per cent of their income in rent. This is especially so for sole parents. The minimum threshold income necessary for first purchasers to buy into the market has risen from 85 per cent of average weekly earnings in 1982 to 145 per cent in 1987. It is no wonder that people need an increase in rental assistance.

Australians are now facing crippling high interest rates which the Prime Minister simply tells them they have to endure. It is no good blaming the banks, as many protesters-the Australians who are being hurt-have been doing in meetings around Australia. The Government determines what the interest rates will be. It is deliberate Government policy. There is no-one to blame but Mr Hawke and his Government. His only response is to say, `You've got to hurt a bit more'. Australia cannot afford the social cost of ignoring these problems. It cannot afford the long term health costs or the cost in terms of crime. Some people have to engage in criminal activities in order to survive and this is a tragic waste of human resources. But the Government does not say that it will assist these people.

I draw attention to the employment issues. Since 1982, the greatest proportional increases in unemployment rates have been in respect of families with three or more children. The duration of unemployment for people seeking full time work is now 47 weeks-a 23 per cent increase from March 1983. The Government claims to have created 1.2 million new jobs. This ignores the fact that we need at least 60,000 new jobs a year just to keep up with the population growth and school leavers. The Institute of Family Studies points to the increase in employment, which means that many one-income families have become two-income families. Many families have been put into this position not because they wish to be but because they can no longer make ends meet on one income-they have been forced to become two-income families. Despite all the rhetoric, the average unemployment level for the Hawke Government has been 8.5 per cent compared with 6.1 per cent for the Fraser years.

As I said, almost 40 per cent of long-term unemployment beneficiaries have three or more children, yet children are our most precious resource. Teenage unemployment is still higher than 20 per cent in some places in Australia. For example, 50 per cent of the unemployed in Ballarat are under 25 years of age, and the total employment rate for the area is twice the national average.

The disgracefully high numbers of children living in poverty demonstrate clearly the failure of the Government to address the real needs of young Australians. They expose the Prime Minister's promise made in the heat of the 1987 election campaign that `No child will live in poverty by 1990'. It was a political stunt of the cheapest and cruellest kind. Surveys have been taken on how credible the Government is when it makes statements concerning that expectation. An overwhelming number of people polled were cynical about the Government's statements and intentions. In a recent Saulwick poll, 85 per cent of voters said that it was unlikely that the Prime Minister's promise would be reached by next year. More than half believed that the proportion of children living in poverty had increased since the promise was made. Eighty-five per cent of Labor voters believed that the promise would not be met. Even the Australian Labor Party faithful do not believe any longer in the rhetoric of this Government.

Can anyone honestly blame these people for not trusting this Government? The economy is off the rails, average Australian families are experiencing crippling high mortgage interest rates and there have been critical reductions in their real disposable incomes. This is a policy which this Government trumpets as the only tool it has to arrest our deteriorating economy. This is the Government that has let people's anger be diverted to the banks. The Government tries to hide behind a shield when it is in fact implementing a high interest rate policy. Is it any wonder that Australian voters think children have suffered and that there is no way that the cheap election promise made in 1987 can ever be delivered? Australian living standards have been significantly eroded under Labor due to bracket creep, high inflation, high interest rates and massive increases in indirect taxation. It is significant that many of the benefits introduced in these Bills are indexed. That alone is an admission that inflation is something which this Government cannot control.

In considering the validity of the promise made by this Government to eradicate child poverty, and in looking at this package of financial assistance in the context of a problem that needs to be dealt with, I think it is significant to look at the Burdekin report into homeless youth and some of its significant findings. The Burdekin report conservatively estimates that 25,000, and possibly as many as 70,000, Australian children have no homes and are living in abject poverty. The April statement took no steps towards increasing assistance to the thousands of homeless children. At the same time it ignores the severe disadvantages suffered by Aboriginal children. The report states:

There has been an almost complete failure to satisfactorily address the needs of our children and many of these kids, I must tell you, are living in the most appalling conditions and in some cases, tragically, they are literally dying.

The strong report from Mr Brian Burdekin-the Commissioner for Human Rights and Equal Opportunity-of the inquiry into youth homelessness, is an indictment of this Government. The report, in criticising the implementation of policies concerning youth, says that there is a lack of information about the youth allowance; there is discouragement of inquiries by departmental staff attitudes; there are breaches of individual privacy and insensitive assessment processes; there are complex application procedures including the time and effort that are required to succeed and there is a requirement for multiple forms for identification and verification procedures. The report goes on and on.

As I said, this package of Bills deals not only with the question of family payments and the indexation of those payments, the family allowance and the family allowance supplement, but also with pensioners and with making changes to the automatic adjustment of social security benefits in line with the movement of the consumer price index (CPI). The automatic twice-yearly indexation of standard pension levels was introduced by the coalition government in May 1977. Each year pension rates were increased in May and November by the increase in the CPI in the six months to the previous December or June, as was relevant. In the 1986 Budget, the Government decided that pensioners should also share in the belt tightening, the same belt tightening that is producing unprecedented high interest rates for home mortgages. The Government expects that the delay in the twice-yearly CPI adjustments of an additional six weeks for wage earners should also be experienced by pensioners. In generosity linked to the fact that there could be an election some time later this year or early next year, plus the fact that the Government is well and truly on the nose with most pensioners, it has had a change of heart.

Given that as the background, the Government has decided that pensioners will not only be spared that six-week wait, but in future the CPI adjustments will be brought forward in three steps, so pension rises will be paid in March and September each year; that is, by 1990 pensions will be indexed every three months following the CPI announcements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did not the Government do it in the first place?

—Because it did not have to face an election in the very near future. Senator Watson has made an excellent point. It is interesting to note the following promise made by the Prime Minister in his 1983 election speech:

SPEECH.PARA: Pensions will be adjusted on the basis of the immediately preceding six-month CPI movement to cut the present lag of four months to one month.

In its seven years of government, Labor has spectacularly broken that promise by blowing out the time lag to six months instead of reducing it to one month, and only by late 1990 will it have reduced it to one month from what it was in 1983, still two months behind schedule. While the repeal of the six-week delay and the speeding up of index- ation increases is welcome, Labor has done nothing to compensate pensioners for the massive monetary losses experienced since it came to power. Since 1986, the additional six-week delay has cost single pensioners $132.90 and married pensioners $108.60 each. The six-month pension indexation delay under Labor has cost the average single pensioner $845 and married pensioners $692 each.

Whilst we welcome the repeal under the veterans' affairs legislation of the 2 per cent discounting of Commonwealth superannu- ation and Defence Force retirement and death benefit pensions from 1 November 1989, Commonwealth superannuants will have lost up to $320 in the meantime. They will not get the 2 per cent back-it is lost for all time under this Government. Indeed, it was only the last line in the 12 April statement that dealt with this pension, so it would be fair to ask: `Was it an afterthought? Was there any real concern?'. I think not. The Government used the rationale that superannuation pensions had increased more than wages and that restraint imposed upon wage earners should be extended to superannuation pensions. However, according to the Superannuated Commonwealth Officers Association, under the Hawke Government superannuation pensions before tax have eroded by more than 5 per cent in comparison with the average wage. The warm inner glow booklet which accompanies the April statement, Towards a Fairer Australia, summarises the pension changes as follows:

These changes to pension and tax arrangements for pensioners demonstrate the high priority which the Government places on assisting the aged and other pensioners and of ensuring that such assistance is directed to those in greatest need.

In the past, automatic indexation has been related only to the standard age pension but with the April statement, additional benefits for mothers' allowances, family allowances et cetera, will also be increased, although they will be adjusted only once a year, in January, for CPI increases in the previous financial year. In the April statement the Government announced that pensioners for the next financial year, commencing 1 July 1989, can earn up to $25 a week for a single pensioner and $70 a week for a married couple, without paying tax or losing any of their pension. Yet the pensioner rebate levels will not be announced until the Budget is brought down. The income earned between 1 July and Budget day, likely to be in the third week of August, will be paid without knowledge of the new pensioner tax rebates, resulting in a free loan by some pensioners to the Government over at least a seven-week period.

This is yet another example of government by press release which has enmeshed this Parliament in so many poor pieces of legislation and which has caused uncertainty in the community and uncertainty for the citizenry. The Prime Minister, the Acting Treasurer, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) cannot grasp the complicated interaction of the social security and taxation systems. Many questions have been put on these issues in the lower House, and they have remained unanswered. We see, in this package of Bills before us today, the implementation of the 12 April statement. As I said, the Opposition welcomes the assistance that is given, but condemns it for being too little too late. It also says, and says firmly, that it is the action of the coalition which has firmly put the question of the family back on the agenda. The Government cannot solve the problems of pressures on families, on homeless youth and on pensioners simply by some tinkering with financial assistance at the edges.

It needs a properly addressed system of policies which will put this economy back on the rails and address the problems of housing and education-the real problems that the Australian people face. The anger of the Australian people against this Government is real. No end of subterfuge or trying to blame the messenger-be it the banks, the Burdekin report, Our Homeless Children, or anybody else-will save the Government from the people's wrath. We welcome the assistance that is given but the Government stands condemned for the false promises it made in 1987 to eradicate child poverty. It will not do it; it will use some specious method of benchmarks to try to say that it has been done. But the Australian people know it has not been done and it will not be done. This Government will pay for that when the election is called.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I go to the substance of what I plan to say this afternoon a few allegations need dealing with immediately. From what Senator Bishop has been telling us it is quite clear that she totally fails to understand the process in which this Government has been engaged, not for the last three months or for the last six or 12 months, but for some years. I will set out to explain that as carefully and as simply as I can. I should immediately challenge her description of the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as scandalous, her accusation that the Government is falling into complacency and that we are tinkering at the edges. For this, I rely not on my opinion, not on the opinions of other members of the Australian Labor Party or, indeed, of the Parliamentary Labor Party, but on the opinion of Bishop Peter Hollingworth, the Executive Director of the Brotherhood of St Laurence, which is acknowledged as an independent expert on family poverty. Very recently on 7 May Bishop Hollingworth, when he gave the George Syme Oration to the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons, said:

SPEECH.PARA: In strict income security terms it is true that the Prime Ministerial promise that `no children shall live in poverty by 1990' will be achieved. This represents significant progress, and demonstrates that governments can meet some modest social justice objectives, even at a time of economic restraint when they are involved in public sector cutbacks and tax reduction in order to improve their economic efficiency.
The Brotherhood of St Laurence, of the Promise the Children campaign, also said:

This pledge, the most specific social commitment of the century, has been the subject of a historic package to provide a guaranteed minimum income for poor children whose parents earn less than about $300 a week. We congratulate the Federal Government on its work on child poverty, which represents a historic breakthrough in the national attack on child poverty. The Federal Government has now built a solid foundation of income security for Australian families.

How did this most specific social commitment of this century come to occur? I would like to describe exactly how this has happened. It goes back some time. As the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) noted in his second reading speech, in 1966 a decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission terminated the long held tradition established by the Harvester decision of 1907 of a male basic wage, which was supposed to fulfil the modest needs of a man, his dependent spouse and two children. There had been crucial flaws in the basic wage as it had been interpreted. These were that the income was never adequate for that prescribed family, that the basic wage was paid to dependent-free males and male heads of large families alike-there was simply no equity in this at all-and that it also allowed a separate lower rate for women on the assumption that women had no dependants. Therefore the basic wage had retarded the introduction of equal pay in most industries for many decades.

In determining a minimum wage, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission gave an impetus to pay equity and clearly laid at the door of the Government that the responsibility of ensuring that social security and taxation systems which transferred assistance to low income households with children was to be the successor to what had theoretically been the employer having that responsibility.

In 1970 Professor Henderson identified the implication of this for public policy making. His report of the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty was instrumental in moves during the Whitlam and Fraser governments, first, to convert tax deductions to rebates and, second, to cash out the rebates and combine them with child endowment to form the family allowance. There was no systematic analysis of such issues for some years, during which most social security payments declined in real terms. Dr Cass's social security review commenced with a thorough study of income support for families and children. It gave us a comprehensive and detailed approach to achieving an assured, adequate, equitable policy for the guidance of the Government. Since the production of that report, I believe in 1985, that document has been used as the basis of the policies which have been put in place over the last three years.

Dr Cass advocated short term measures, which have now been progressively implemented over the past two years. Firstly, there is the family allowance supplement, which of course is payable to the principal carer of children, directed to the mother in the majority of cases. Secondly, there is a child disability payment, which removes a previous distinction, which meant that many families with disabled children were not being acknowledged as in need of that payment and raised the quantum to $112 per month. Thirdly, there are differential rates for younger and older children, recognising the fact that teenage children are very expensive to maintain. Fourthly, there have been massive increases in payments, which I will go to in a moment. Finally, there has been the integration of family allowance and the family allowance supplement, providing predictability in the extra income upon which people can rely.

The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, which puts into place the April statement initiatives of this year, introduces longer term recommendations of Professor Cass. For example, the family allowance increased only a very small amount-from $3.10 to $5.25-during the Fraser years. One small allowance in seven years was the only increase in that particular payment. During the time of the Labor Government it has been increased from $5.25 to $9 for the first, second and third children and $12 for the fourth child and subsequent children. This once again acknowledges the extra cost of older children and larger families. As was advocated by Dr Cass, this will pay a basic family rate-a flat rate-with special recognition for larger families. Almost two million families with a total of 3.8 children will benefit from this increased family allowance payment, which will be indexed. At the same time we have considerably increased and indexed the dependent spouse rebate and the sole parent rebate.

Senator Bishop made really quite cutting remarks about indexation, which she believed was introduced simply as an admission of a failure to reduce or entirely eliminate inflation. It is in fact an acknowledgment of a fact of life-these payments will decrease in their value unless they are indexed. She tells us with great pride that the Fraser Government indexed pensions. I do not quite see what distinction there is between the worth of indexing age pensions and somehow or other the specious quality in indexing payments for families. In any case, this is an absolutely crucial measure which we now introduce.

At the 1987 election we promised that during Labor's third term an adequate living standard for children would be achieved by raising child payments to ensure that total assistance per child equalled at least 15 per cent of the combined rate of married pension and that the aggregate payment for older children would be at a benchmark of 20 per cent of the combined married pension rate. That standard was set, for the first time in Australia's history. That is what Bishop Hollingworth was referring to when he talked about-as I quoted earlier-`the most specific social commitment of the century and an historic breakthrough' and the fact that we have established a standard.

I have heard nothing whatsoever from the Opposition about any alternative standard or any analysis of whether the standard is adequate or otherwise. I have heard nothing about whether there should be a standard. I am waiting breathlessly to hear what exactly, if anything, its objection to the standard that has been established is. It was not done lightly. As I have said several times, the standard was set for the first time in Australia's history as a result of Australian research into the income needs of families with children, and it will be maintained in real terms by indexation. That is a matter from which I take considerable satisfaction. I believe that, among other things-at this moment I am not even looking at the equity and social justice of it-it will begin to return Australia to the pre-eminent position we had in international terms many decades ago in the way in which we were able to provide social assistance to our population.

For the first time we have a guaranteed income which is higher in real terms than that advocated by Professor Henderson. As I said before, we have guaranteed that the aggregate of payment to children up to the age of 12 will be 15 per cent of the combined marriage pension rate, that the aggregate of the payment to children aged from 13 to 15 will be 20 per cent of the combined married pension rate and that-although it is not covered in this Bill-for 16- and 17-year-olds the payment will be 25 per cent of the combined married pension rate. That payment is of enormous significance to homeless youth, who would otherwise, in many cases, have no income maintenance at all. The addition to what has been paid previously to those groups of people will bring them into the realms of real, non-taxed amounts of money which have made a substantial difference to a large number of Australian families and their children.

The figures quoted by Senator Bishop are ones which she has seen in the newspapers. What she failed to note was that they are 1986 figures, compiled before the introduction of the family allowance supplement at the beginning of 1987. She quoted 800,000 children living in poverty of whom only 30 per cent will be assisted by our measures. At this stage all those children, or their families, should be receiving the family allowance supplement and from 1 July they will receive the increased family allowance. That will make an enormous difference to their standard of living. For younger children the aggregate payment will be $33 per week each and, for older children, $43.10 per week. That is a substantial increase on the previous amount.

Our commitment to indexation is also breaking new ground. Payments which will be indexed are the family allowance, the mother's/guardian's allowance, and the others to which I referred earlier-the dependent spouse rebate, the sole parent rebate and, I believe, the payment for handicapped children. These payments will be indexed from the first payday in 1990 and then annually in line with consumer price index movements in previous years. The family allowance supplement, additional pension rates and additional benefits will be adjusted from the first payday of each calendar year to ensure that total payments are guaranteed as a percentage of the married pension rate, which is automatically indexed.

I come back to the point I was making before. This is the benchmark that has been established as a result of very detailed work done in conjunction with the Institute of Family Studies, produced by Professor Cass and decided upon by the Government as an appropriate benchmark, as I have also noted, higher than the one suggested by Professor Henderson; yet we have heard not one word from the Opposition about how it would deal with this challenge. I am particularly amused to discover that Senator Bishop believes that the plight of families is back on the agenda as a result of the production of Future Directions-that Future Directions is responsible for this. I am quite amazed. I was under the impression that the document Future Directions was seen only in the last few months and, as I have pointed out, the work which the Government has been doing on this question goes back some years. This legislation is not a flash in the pan. It has been in preparation for some years.

As I have said, we have introduced short term and long term measures and have set in place the means whereby the standards should be maintained through indexation so that never again will we be faced with a Budget process in which families get what is left over at the end. We have established and systematised a means whereby we have been able to assess what is required to assist low income families. We have produced the means by which we can assist them. We have also been able through this legislation to introduce a means whereby those payments will retain their worth.

Talking about Future Directions reminds me that it is accompanied by a most amazing jingle which does not seem to have a great deal of empathy with average Australian families, let alone low income Australian families. The jingle is addressed almost solely to the male of the species. It starts:
Son, you're an Australian. That's enough for anyone to be. Australia needs plain thinking men like you.
Further down it states:
I grew to be a proud man.
Once again, towards the end it states:
Son, you're an Australian.

I believe that that would be quite insulting to many Australian families. There is no doubt about the role of the Australian male, but when we talk about low income families-families in poverty, families in need of particular assistance-we are looking at a great number of families headed by women. We are looking at being able to provide to the principal carer of children, in the vast majority of cases a woman, that assistance, encouragement, secure income and confidence which, in many cases, we hope will take that person back into the work force, out of poverty and into independence. That is by far the best way that anybody has devised so far of lifting households out of poverty.

As the Minister said in his second reading speech, never again will the standards of living of low income families with children be subject to decimation through policy indolence and lethargy of governments. We will deliver for all children-whether they live in two or one-parent families, whether one parent, both parents or no parent works, or whether they live in institutions. That is the emphasis, the intention, of the package of legislation with which we are dealing today.

I wish to quote from the Institute of Family Studies' Families and the Tax Package, which states exactly what the Institute believes we are achieving as a result of the April announcements. The Institute states:
The Government's commitment to increase payments for children to specific benchmarks as a measure against child poverty has been fulfilled.

There is no doubt about that. There is nothing scandalous or cynical about it; it is a very straight statement of fact. In regard to one of the propositions which we hear every now and then from the Opposition which I believe has been thoroughly discredited, it might be interesting to note what the Institute of Family Studies thinks about income splitting. It has stated:

Income splitting would provide least assistance to lower and middle income families, especially those on only one income, the group it is purportedly aimed at helping. Indeed such families receiving less than about $19,000 per annum would pay more tax as a result. Sole parent families would receive nothing from such a proposal.
Approximately 48 per cent of the cost would go to families with incomes above $40,000 per annum and only 6 per cent would go to families with incomes below AWE.

The income splitting proposal would create very severe work disincentives for married women at a time when the labour market is expanding and requires greater flexibility and a higher skill base rather than new and inappropriate rigidities.

I include that information in response to Senator Bishop's suggestion of the inability of this Government to initiate interacting measures between taxation and social security which would deal with the problems of families on very low incomes. I have said it several times before but I will say it again: this package of legislation is the result of years of serious analysis and serious policy implementation. Its effects will be felt, maybe, in perpetuity-perhaps that is a little optimistic for any government to predict.

I now refer to other measures which are to be introduced as a result of this legislation. The Government has decided to ensure that the income test free area for pensioners will become 100 per cent tax free. This will be achieved by setting the pensioner tax rebates at appropriate levels. Pensioners will welcome this measure very strongly. There has been a great deal of anxiety and confusion about taxable income and income test areas. The cost of implementing this measure is not very large and it is well worth introducing. The Government has managed to bring forward the pension indexation increases in three stages-a matter that rankled with many pensioners-so that indexation rates will be brought forward in total by 12 weeks. The Government has made another decision, which has been welcomed very widely by pensioners, that about 750,000 of them will not be paying provisional tax. All pensioners receiving pensioner tax rebates will be exempted from paying provisional tax.

Other measures that are included in the Bill make it clear that the family of a disabled child is entitled to a child disability allowance regardless of whether the mother or the father cares for the child. That clears up some confusion. There is now an entitlement to a one-off double payment of benefit to ex-prisoners. This entitlement will be extended to former long term beneficiaries who reclaim unemployment benefit on release from prisons within three months of last receiving unemployment benefit. The plight of prisoners who leave prison with no support, no income, is one that has been recognised by this Government.

Reference has been made to privacy issues by Senator Bishop. Were she to read the Bill, she would be reassured to discover that it will increase penalties for the unauthorised disclosure of client information. The penalties currently provided by the Act on summary conviction for unlawful disclosure are up to six months imprisonment or a $1,000 fine. On indictment an offender can face a gaol term of up to two years or a fine of up to $5,000. This Bill would raise the fines for breaches of the secrecy provisions contained in the Social Security Act to $3,000 on summary conviction and $12,000 on indictment. It must be agreed that those fines provide a very substantial disincentive.

All members of the Government are extremely gratified by the fact that we have been involved in a process whereby Australian households on low incomes, be they beneficiaries or in receipt of low wages, currently are being substantially assisted, and will be substantially assisted in the future, by what we will be able to do. Many households now receive at least $40 per week tax free which they were not receiving 18 months ago. They can look forward to providing for their children in the knowledge that those payments will continue in line with the benchmark which we have established. Those families know that this Government has their concerns very much at heart.

We know perfectly well that by assuring incomes we are not eradicating all aspects of poverty. We have no doubt that housing is extremely important. This Government has invested a great deal more in housing than the previous one did. We know that lifting people out of unemployment and into independence is extremely important and many of our measures along these lines have been extremely effective. We know that making it possible for young people to obtain adequate education is one of the best ways in which we can increase opportunities for them. We know, too, that the health of the whole population is absolutely crucial to its overall well-being. In that respect, having heard another debate this morning, I am beginning to feel extremely alarmed about the Opposition's intentions. The future of our national, universal health scheme seems as if it may be in considerable doubt in the hands of other than a Labor government. This lack of recognition by the Opposition of the enormous significance of access by the community to good health services bothers me more than anything else the notion that whoever can pay for good health care gets good health care. I find that particularly disturbing in the context of this debate. This is a Bill which enacts the promises of the Government's April statement. I commend it to the Senate.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.43 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, follows the question asked by Senator Chaney yesterday about the gross violations of human rights and political freedoms which have been occurring in China with very little protest, it seems, from the Australian Government for several years. I ask the Minister whether he now has the information sought by Senator Chaney about the extent of the long term oppression of human rights by the Chinese Government and, in particular, the details of any protests from the Australian Government about such action. I further ask the Minister: Is it a fact that between 5 and 8 March this year Chinese authorities killed about 200 unarmed students, monks and other young people in Tibet who were demonstrating in support of greater freedom? What protest did the Australian Government make about this slaughter? Will the Minister table any relevant note or correspondence? Did the Government take this atrocity into consideration in assessing the likelihood that the Chinese Government would use brutal force to end the protest in Tiananmen Square?

—Yesterday I was asked similar questions by Senator Hill and Senator Chaney about this matter. I was asked particularly to table a letter which the Prime Minister had sent to the Chinese Premier at the beginning of this week.
—No; that is a different question.

—No; I am covering both questions. The Prime Minister has asked me to say that, as a matter of policy and practice, he does not release the contents of his private correspondence with foreign heads of government on issues of ongoing policy importance. But, in view of the public interest in the recent events in China, he has agreed to make an exception in this case. I therefore formally table the letter dated 12 June which the Prime Minister sent, although I think the letter may already be public.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That is all very interesting, but what about the question that I asked? In the form of a supplementary question I will go through it again. The first part of my question concerned the question asked yesterday by Senator Chaney about the gross violations that have been occurring in China. In particular, he asked whether the Minister would advise the Senate what actions Australia has been taking to protest against such violations and whether the Minister would provide a schedule for the Senate. The second part of my question, which added to Senator Chaney's question, concerned the atrocity that occurred in Tibet between 5 and 8 March this year when about 200 students, monks and other unarmed young people who were protesting for greater freedom were slaughtered. I asked: What protest did the Australian Government make about that occurrence? Furthermore, did the Australian Government take that into account when determining the likelihood that the Chinese Government would use brutal force to end the protest in Tiananmen Square?
—I have said that the Prime Minister has asked me to say that, as a matter of normal policy and practice, he does not make public his communications with foreign heads of government.
—You sat around sipping tea--

—We could have some Claytons sanctions-I suppose that is what the honourable senator would like us to do-like that great humbug and fraud Malcolm Fraser had in 1980. He imposed Claytons trade sanctions in a protest against both the Russian invasion of Afghanistan and the events in Iran. What were those sanctions? The first was, `We will not sell wool to Iran'. That was a bold move because Iran did not buy any wool. We did not say anything about not selling grain to Iran because Iran bought grain. However, being very bold, sanctimonious and upright, Malcolm Fraser said, `We will not sell any more grain to the Russians than we sold in the previous year', which just happened to be more grain than we had ever sold to Russia in the past. He did not say anything about not selling wool to Russia because, of course, the Russians bought a lot of wool, including as it was ultimately revealed, the Nareen wool clip, which was loaded into a Russian ship at Portland. If honourable senators opposite want that sort of humbug and those sorts of hypocritical trade sanctions-things that they used to do when they were in government when one of the greatest humbugs and frauds of all time--
—Order! The Minister's answer is not relevant to the question.

—Mr President, it is highly relevant to the sanctimony being displayed by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. I have said what the Prime Minister has authorised me to say. He does not make a habit of making public his private correspondence, but in this case he has.

—Does the Minister representing the Treasurer recall the campaign waged by the National Farmers Federation against the Government's 1985 initiatives to rationalise the taxation of fringe benefits? What do Australian Taxation Office statistics indicate about the amount of fringe benefits tax (FBT) paid by the farm sector? Has the incidence of the FBT been such as to place a major burden on Australia's farm sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall the National Farmers Federation campaign very well. I also recall that the then President of the National Farmers Federation played a high profile role in that campaign against both the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. Of course, it provided Mr McLachlan with a vehicle for obtaining a high profile in the media and among conservative string pullers, on which he apparently continues to ride. I also understand that it used up a great deal of the National Farmers Federation's money and effort.

ANSWER.PARA: The statistics that are now available show-and anybody who knew anything about agriculture at the time would have known it anyway-that the FBT had very little effect on farmers; the constituency which Mr McLachlan was purporting to represent. The publication by the Australian Taxation Office Taxation Statistics 1986-87, published late last month, contains a number of tables of statistics on the FBT during the period 1 April 1987 to 31 March 1988. Total FBT collections for that period were $859m and, of that, $15.3m, or 1.8 per cent, was paid by taxpayers in the farm sector. Of course, that included companies and partnerships, as well as sole trader farmers. A little over $2m of that $15m was paid by public companies. So a maximum of $13.3m was paid by farmer taxpayers who can be genuinely regarded as farmers. That means that 1 1/2 per cent of total FBT was paid by--

TALK.START.PARA: —And the rest.

—If the honourable senator wants to dispute the officially published statistics of the Commissioner of Taxation, that is his affair. Personally, I would not. One and a half per cent of the total FBT was paid by farmers, who account for about 5 1/2 per cent of the work force. Of course, that reveals that the farm sector-as anybody who knows anything about the farm sector or who was concerned about that sector would have known-was not one of those areas in which payments in cash had been converted into payments in kind in order to escape tax. The main area where this sort of thing was rife was among senior executives of large companies, such as Elders-IXL and the South Australian Brewing Co. Ltd-a couple of companies which Mr McLachlan would know all about.

ANSWER.PARA: Going back to the first part of the question, at that time Mr McLachlan supported incentives to dodge tax and he fought hard to retain those incentives by converting cash payments into payments in kind. He then used the subscriptions of ordinary farmers to fight a campaign to further his own interests and those of his rich fellow directors-mostly city-based-of companies such as Elders-IXL and the South Australian Brewing Co.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer him to the Prime Minister's letter to the Chinese Premier, Li Peng, which gives scant emphasis to the murderous conduct of the Chinese authorities and virtually turns a blind eye to the evidence of continuing repression and revenge in China. Are Australians to understand from the tone of the Prime Minister's letter that, as far as the Labor Government is concerned, the sooner we get back to business as usual with the Chinese regime, the better?

—Nobody in the Government has said that, including the Prime Minister. The construction that Senator Puplick wants to put on the Prime Minister's letter to draw that conclusion is a very distorted and twisted one.
—Have you read his note?

—I thank Senator Hill. He asked one question earlier today and persists with his ratbrained interjections every time a Minister is on his feet. Nobody in his right mind can put that construction on the Prime Minister's letter. The fact is that the letter was an early expression of concern from the leader of the Government in Australia-probably earlier than many other letters sent by international leaders. It fully sets out the concern and distress of the Australian people over events in China. To put on it the construction that Senator Puplick seeks to put is gilding the lily, to say the least.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I refer Senator Button again to the Prime Minister's letter, and in particular, to quote the Prime Minister's words, to the fact that the Australian Government `has been active in spreading the good word about developments in China and their significance among our neighbours in Asia and the Pacific and among western countries with which we have close relations'. I also note the Prime Minister's reference to `the constructive role China has played in our neighbourhood and on the international stage'. I ask: In spreading the so-called good word, has the Government taken into account that China's actions in its most immediate neighbourhood-I refer to its brutal repression of the people of Tibet-are worthy only of condemnation, not praise? Does the Prime Minister regard the rape of Tibet as constituting the constructive role that China has played in our neighbourhood?

—Senator Puplick's supplementary question just reveals the intellectual defects in his original question. His original question was about the Prime Minister's letter. He was seeking to construe out of that letter a suggestion that the Australian Government was seeking business as usual, as he put it, with China. He cannot draw that conclusion from the Prime Minister's letter. So, in his supplementary question, he came back to a totally different issue about which there can be no doubt. There is no doubt that the Australian Government over a period of years-as have all Australian governments over a period of years-has sought constructive relations with China, has sought to bring China into the sphere of influence, if you like, of countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and has supported, for example, China's application to join various international organisations.
—He was duped.

—All those things, in my view, were good things to do. Senator Walters reveals the full depth of the intellectual content of the Opposition's probing on this issue by saying that he was duped. That might be so. Millions of Chinese people may have been duped. Leaders of countries such as the United States of America, the United Kingdom and so on may not have anticipated what occurred in Beijing in the last few weeks. Not many people did. Nobody in the Opposition did because, if it had occurred to members of the Opposition at any time, they would have asked the question: `Is the Australian Government taking the right attitude'-to use Senator Puplick's words-`in embracing China into the community of nations, by advocating its cause in various forums and so on?'. If members of the Opposition had been alert to that issue, if they had suspected for a moment that these events were likely to arise, and as, presumably, they consider themselves part of a smart Opposition, they would have asked questions about that. But they never did-not one of them. Now, being wise after the event, they pop up with these sorts of questions. As I have said, they are drawing a very long bow. But I understand their need to do that.

—I refer the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to reports that on Monday the mining company Central Queensland Cement Pty Ltd destroyed Mount Etna's Speaking Tube caves, the winter roost for the rare ghost bat. Is this an area in which the Federal Government has any jurisdiction? If so, can any Federal action be taken about such a level of environmental vandalism? If the Federal Government has no jurisdiction in this matter, can the Minister voice his disapproval to the Queensland Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have on previous occasions voiced my disapproval at what has been going on with Central Queensland Cement at Mount Etna. This latest example, taking place as it did on the public holiday on Monday, is yet another appalling example of the Queensland Government's attitude to the Queensland environment. The Speaking Tube cave at Mount Etna is an important winter roosting site for the ghost bat. Unfortunately, the ghost bat could become an endangered species. I assure Senator Colston that I also wrote to the company at the time and expressed my disappointment and disapproval. I will be doing the same thing again in the next few days. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Can the Minister give details of the invitation from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) to Australia, along with Japan, China, New Zealand, India and the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations, to send observers to a Soviet naval exercise in the Sea of Japan next month? Is this invitation in the spirit of the Prime Minister's call for the United States of America and the USSR to negotiate confidence building and arms control measures in the Asia-Pacific region, which he made in the House of Representatives on 29 May this year? Will the Government accept the invitation?

—I cannot answer that question in terms of the acceptance or otherwise of the invitation. Whether or not the invitation is accepted will depend on a variety of factors, including the attitudes of other countries which have been invited to participate and send observers. I will try to find an early answer to the question. —I direct my question to the Minister for Resources. In early 1988 the Government deregulated the market for domestically produced crude oil and removed export controls on crude oils produced in Australia. What have been the benefits of deregulating the crude oil market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is correct that the Government at the beginning of last year enacted significant micro-economic reform by bringing in a deregulation of the Australian domestic crude oil market. When we took office in 1983 the major proportion of domestic crude oil production was marketed in Australia under a voluntary crude oil allocation scheme whereby shares of production from each field were allocated to each Australian refiner. The price of these sales was set by the Government's import parity pricing policy, as it then was, and production in excess of the allocated quantity could be sold on the domestic free market or exported, although producers were required to obtain approval for each export sale. When we came to power there was a regulated market in Australia, carried on by the Fraser Government, in crude oil production.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1988 we enacted the most significant reform in crude oil marketing since the crude oil allocation scheme in 1965 or the import parity pricing scheme in 1978. We did this to bring efficiencies in the refining and distribution of Australian crude and to expose, in a declining self-sufficiency environment, Australian crude oil producers to much more of the international market so that they could read the signals of that market and take their place as exporters or importers, as the case may be, aware of the circumstances of the international climate.

The deregulation has spawned a number of particular advantages for the Australian refinery industry which I should mention. Not only have Australian producers now become proficient traders on the world market but also, in terms of the refinery area, British Petroleum Co. of Australia Ltd at Kwinana in Western Australia has commissioned a residue cracking unit capable of processing heavier imported crude oils. That is quite significant because Asian crudes contain a high wax content and we now have a capacity in Australia to deal with that. I cannot give the Senate a figure because that is a commercial in confidence investment.

Ampol Ltd has commenced construction of a platformer at its Lytton refinery in Brisbane which will produce high octane blend stock for unleaded petrol. Investment will be more than $100m and the unit is scheduled for completion in the second half of 1990. The Shell Co. of Australia Ltd plans to undertake investment of $200m for extension and upgrading of the Clyde refinery in Sydney and $400m for a catalytic cracking unit at its Geelong refinery. They are a number of efficiencies that our move to deregulation has induced in the refinery area.

The Department of Resources' most recent contact with oil producers and refiners to monitor their reaction to the deregulation environment, which is now coming up to its 18-month anniversary, has revealed that what they originally perceived with perhaps reticence and tentativeness is now hailed by them as a necessary, valuable and welcomed reform.

It is necessary to conclude by saying that this is yet another example of the Government's inexorable move to micro-economic reform of the Australian economy. This micro-economic reform of a market that was regulated under the Liberals and deregulated under this Government has brought about efficiencies and investment. It is a good example of achievement by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is it a fact that the Australian Manufacturing Council has commissioned a $1.5m consultancy to review the competitiveness of Australian industry? Why was this job not given to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) or the Bureau of Industry Economics? Is it because the Minister knew that either of these bodies was likely to produce an unpalatably tough assessment-no doubt to do with deregulation, as we have just heard from Senator Cook-and, just as happened with the Inter-State Commission report on the waterfront, the Government would then be embarrassed because it would not be allowed by the unions to implement the recommendations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I might say so, that question has a superficial charm about it. But let us look at some of the detail. The answer to the question is yes, the Australian Manufacturing Council has commissioned a consultants' report-both international consultants and Australian consultants-to look at issues associated with both firm and structural competitiveness of the Australian manufacturing sector. That is not a study commissioned by the Government as such; it is commissioned by the Manufacturing Council. The cost of the study will be shared by Commonwealth and State governments and the private sector. A number of firms are contributing to that. The consultancy will undoubtedly focus on a number of issues which go to the competitiveness of individual firms and firm performance. I welcome that as a contribution to an ongoing discussion about these issues.

ANSWER.PARA: Why was it not referred to the IAC? I do not think any of the businesses involved or the State governments would have wanted to refer it to the IAC. I do not think the subject is within the province of the IAC in terms of the breadth of the inquiry that is being conducted. The Bureau of Industry Economics does not have the function of looking at these issues in the broad. We could set up, if you like, a competitive evaluation by the Bureau of Industry Economics, but a lot of the issues which are being looked at are not, in my view, susceptible to the wisdom of classical economists. That is why it is being done in that way.

Senator Lewis asked whether there is some apprehension that, if it were referred to the IAC, we might get a tough report. This Government has had plenty of tough reports. In respect of the traditional role of the IAC in looking at the burdens imposed on highly protected industries, on export industries, I believe that this Government has adopted something like 96 per cent of IAC recommendations. There have been differences. For example, the IAC represented a particular long term tariff level in respect of the chemical industry and the Government adopted a lower level. That is a very big industry. There have been exceptions like that where the Government, to use Senator Lewis's term, adopted a considerably tougher approach than the one recommended by the IAC. So again, if I might say so, Senator Lewis should do his homework before he couches a question in this form. As usual, as I expect from Senator Lewis, the question had a beguiling charm about it which concealed a lack of information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. As to the contribution from the private sector, could the Minister indicate whether those moneys are coming from the trade union movement, from businesses or from both; if so, in what proportions and about how much? Could the Minister indicate whether he anticipates that this report is likely to try to pick winners with regard to either sectors of manufacturing or individual manufacturing businesses in the country?

—With regard to the second part of the question, that is very much a matter for the consultants to determine. But I would certainly think that they would not be about the question of picking winners in terms of firms. They would be about, presumably, if they are in their right minds, picking areas of long term comparative competitive advantage for Australian industry sectors. I do not think that is a bad thing. I am not sure whether or not the trade union movement, through the Australian Council of Trade Unions, is contributing to the funds for the consultancy. I know that a number of large businesses are contributing. I will find out about that.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to an article published in the Gold Coast Bulletin on 9 June in which Senator Sheil repeats earlier published assertions that the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) makes available for sale data on `individual, family and household income . . . mortgage details, occupation, religion, rental payments, and even school leaving ages'? Does the Minister agree that Senator Sheil's allegations may be construed as implying that personal and confidential information supplied on census forms may be selectively available for sale to any interested party and include its use by private enterprise? Does the Minister agree that the fear of lack of protection for confidential information supplied by individuals could arouse substantial suspicion and mistrust by the public in providing detailed information on census forms? Does the Minister agree that the accuracy of data obtained in the next national census could be jeopardised by the deliberate dissemination of incorrect or misleading information? In the interests of maintaining public confidence in the census process, is the Minister able to refute Senator Sheil's allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can certainly refute the allegations although previous experience suggests that it will not prevent Senator Sheil from making the same allegations again. I straightened him out on 31 May but then, as Senator Burns states in his question, Senator Sheil repeated almost exactly the same misinformation and was reported in the Gold Coast Bulletin of 9 June. I quote the paragraph which I think Senator Burns may also have quoted. Senator Sheil said that one can buy information from the Australian Bureau of Statistics and that:

ANSWER.PARA: It includes everything from individual, family and household income . . . mortgage details, occupation, religion, rental payments, and even school leaving ages.

That can certainly be construed by a reasonable person as asserting that, if he wants to know all those details about anybody, all he has to do is ring up the ABS, pay and the Bureau will give the information to him. The statement can certainly be construed in that way. Whether Senator Sheil meant to have it construed in that way is, I suppose, a matter of opinion although his recidivism in this matter certainly suggests that his deliberate intention is to mislead the public about the degree to which information on the individual is available. Information about individuals is never made available by the ABS. The ABS makes available aggregated information about a large number of people on things like income stratification, levels of education and so on. It is correct to say that that sort of information is sold to the public.

As I pointed out before, there would be little point in conducting a census if that sort of information were not available to people in the private sector, State and local governments and so on. It is important for planning purposes, not the least of which, for example, is the provision of schools for education. In order to get a reasonable fix on that it is necessary to know how many preschool age children there are, where they live and what their ages are.

As I said, Senator Sheil's recidivism on this matter suggests to me that he is deliberately attempting to mislead the public. I would like to think that that is wrong and that he just failed to understand it yet again, but I guess the test will come as to whether he continues to make these baseless, scurrilous and-I think it is not too strong to say-subversive allegations. If the campaign which Senator Sheil appears to be running were successful, people would, as Senator Burns's question suggests, be reluctant to complete census forms accurately. Certainly some people would be reluctant to do so. That would mean that the bulk of aggregate statistics that comes out of a census would be less reliable than it would otherwise be. The consequences of that are negative for the Commonwealth, local and State governments and for a number of people in the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Minister representing the Prime Minister, arises out of certain recidivist tendencies being displayed by the Prime Minister. I refer to reports this morning that, having met some home buyers last week, the Prime Minister wants urgent attention given to ways of helping people who are suffering because of his own high interest rate policy. Is the Government, as reported, considering tax deductability for mortgage payments? Does the Minister share the concern expressed by Senator Walsh yesterday about the impact of such deductability on diverting capital investment from other areas and on Government revenue?

—I share Senator Walsh's concern as expressed yesterday. I fully understand the point which Senator Walsh was making and I agree with it. In so far as observations by the Prime Minister are concerned, he and all Government Ministers have said that they are very aware that the present levels of interest rates are hurting home loan borrowers. Of course, that is something Government Ministers hope will not continue for longer than is demanded in the interests of the economy as a whole and the slowing of demand. The idea of an interest rate subsidy is not a new one; it has been around for a long time. Further consideration of an interest rate subsidy would require a great deal of work to see that the effects that Senator Walsh referred to did not occur.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like to draw the Minister a little further and ask him to elaborate on the last comment he made in response to my earlier question. Does he agree with the comments of the present Treasurer who, when announcing in May 1983 the phase-out of a somewhat similar scheme, described it as a highly inequitable scheme?

—I suppose any of those schemes are distortionary, and to that extent inequitable as between borrowers. I do not recall the scheme to which the Treasurer referred in 1983. I suppose it was one introduced by the previous Government.
—It was one of Fraser's 1982 specials.
—It was part of the 1982 special. It was probably phased out for quite sensible and rational reasons.
—Is the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer aware that Mr Ian McLachlan, a director of Mr John Elliot's Elders-IXL Ltd--
—Is it McLachlan bashing day today?

—Do honourable senators opposite not listen to Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) radio in the mornings? I do. Mr McLachlan was reported on ABC radio this morning as calling for greater incentives in Australia's taxation system.

—The question really does not deserve this sort of applause but I will continue. What sort of incentives would the abolition of the Government's 1985 capital gains tax reforms produce? Does the Government have any plans to water down the capital gains tax in the ways that have been called for by various directors of Elders-IXL?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard Mr McLachlan on the wireless this morning. I can think immediately of one type of incentive which the abolition of capital gains tax would provide. Likewise, the watering down of capital gains tax as proposed by the Liberal Party of Australia would provide the same incentive, that is the incentive for directors and senior executives of public companies to provide themselves with what are euphemistically called executive share incentive schemes. In the Elders scheme, for example, the favoured few are granted 1c paid shares in the company. Incidentally, according to Elders's most recent annual report, of September 1988, Mr Ian McLachlan was a holder of 42,000 of those 1c paid shares.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, the abolition of capital gains tax would strengthen the incentive to make bonus issues of shares to shareholders and to allow holdings of those 1c paid shares to be treated as if they were fully paid for the purpose of such bonus issues. Incidentally, Elders offered or declared a one for five bonus on 28 September last year, including a bonus on those 1c paid shares, 42,000 of which are owned by Mr McLachlan. So he would have received 8,400 bonus shares as a consequence of the 1c paid shares he had previously taken up under what is, as I said before, euphemistically called the executive share incentive scheme. Those 8,400 shares would be worth a bit over $21,000 at yesterday's price. If Mr McLachlan were to sell those shares he would pay-this is only the bonus issue part of it-capital gains tax at the marginal rate of personal tax applicable to him. If, however, the capital gains tax were to be abolished, he would pay nothing. If the Liberal Party's proposal were to be implemented, if he held them for five years he would pay nothing; if he held them for one year, he would pay only 80 per cent of what he would be liable to pay under the existing law.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a good scheme.
—Senator Hill thinks that is a good thing, does he?
—I said it was a good tax.

—Senator Hill said it was a good tax in 1981. I am sorry; I do not wish to defame Senator Hill. That applies only to the bonus shares which were issued as a result of the 42,000 1c shares previously made available to Mr McLachlan. If he sold all the 42,000 shares, the tax that he would evade or avoid would blow out to in excess of $100,000 capital gains tax. The executive incentive share scheme is a mechanism by which those who are in control of companies effectively diddle all other shareholders in companies. If the gains are to be exempt from capital gains taxation on the sale of the shares, that diddles all the other taxpayers as well. I do not think I need say any more.

—Is the Minister for Justice absolutely certain, and can he provide the Senate with a categorical undertaking, that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) production Police State, if shown on television throughout Australia, can in no way prejudice the guilt or innocence of people named or referred to in the course of the Queensland Government's Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct?

—It should be obvious to any senator that I would be totally unable to give such an unequivocal assurance, as I have had no sighting of the film concerned. Obviously, there are matters of balance and public interest to be weighed up in relation to the portrayal of alleged events in Queensland and the prospect of certain trials that may be undertaken, but as I understand it the designated Special Prosecutor in Queensland has had an opportunity to see the proposed video-I am going on radio reports-and some compromise has been reached between the ABC and the Queensland authorities. But I am not sure of that.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister did not really answer the question I asked. I am endeavouring to ascertain whether the Minister, as the spokesman for the Government, is satisfied that the actions of the ABC could not prejudice a fair trial in due course to various people who may have been named or referred to in various ways in the course of the trial and whether he is satisfied that if the production goes on air he will bear the brunt of the responsibility?

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs, relates to recently announced decisions of the Government concerning food processing. Can the Minister indicate what decisions have been made on food packaging and what steps the Government will take to ensure that consumers are not disadvantaged by those decisions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government announced last week a number of measures in the food processing and beverages industry after an interim report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC), which came down in February of this year. The decision of the Government is basically in two parts. In respect of the current laws on the mandatory composition and information labelling of food, the Government found a number of recommendations from the IAC and also had to assess those recommendations not in purely a financial cost benefit analysis but also in a broader context.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government believes that information which is available to consumers is vital. The compositional standards are vital to the extent that they provide necessary protection to consumers. To that effect, we have not taken immediate action. What we have done in those two areas is to recognise that not only financial considerations but also long term health costs are involved, as well as the consumers' right to adequate protection. Having recognised all those factors and recognising also that we are dealing with an increasingly sophisticated area of production, we decided that these particular areas should be further examined by the current food law enforcement and regulating bodies. As such, all those other considerations which will give consumers adequate information and choice will be considered by the appropriate bodies. We believe that consumers have to make informed choices, taking into consideration nutritional health and dietary qualities.

The other part of the Government's decision was in the area of regulations specifying standard package sizes. In that particularly complex area we have decided that this part of the food law should be repealed. It should be noted that the area is a very complex one. At the moment, less than 50 per cent of this part of the food industry is standardised, but we find a number of anomalies. We find arbitrary, inconsistent, redundant legislation. We find that there is no real consistency between what is standardised and what is not. At the end of the day, the regulations in this area have done two things. First, they have led to confusion for consumers. Secondly, they have probably led to extra costs, not only to industry but also to consumers.

It should also be noted that in coming to this position the Government had to take into account the fact that quite often regulations in this area are used as trade barriers. So we have agreed to adopt and implement as policy the deregulation of standard package sizes. We are also concerned to protect consumers in this context. As a consequence, the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs will monitor the operations of deregulation in this area, in the first instance to assess whether difficulties accrue and secondly to suggest ways of addressing the problems. In that context, from time to time one can look at specific responses, but unit pricing might be one that can be considered if deregulation has unforeseen consequences.

We feel that the most appropriate way in which consumers can be protected is to ensure that there are effective, relevant and non-anachronistic codes to cover deceptive packaging. To that effect the Trade Practices Commission will play a role in implementing this part of the decision. Accordingly, the Government's decision in two parts will have the effect not only of protecting consumers but also of reducing costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to answer a question Senator Reid asked me in Question Time yesterday concerning Indo-Chinese refugees. ANSWER.PARA: In answer to the last part of the question, the comprehensive plan of action states that persons determined as not being refugees should return to their country of origin and encourages the voluntary return of such persons in the first instance.
