The Government supports the principle that people who are determined as not being refugees under the 1951 United Nations Convention and the 1967 protocol relating to the status of refugees, to which Australia is a signatory, are expected to return to their country of origin under conditions of safety and dignity in accordance with international practice.

Science and Personnel,
Parliament House,
Canberra ACT 2600

TALK.START.PARA: —This interim report calls on the Government to emphasise its existing commitment to drug-free sport in Australia. Its recommendations deal with the mechanisms that are needed to ensure that athletes do not use performance enhancing drugs. They also deal with the controls that are required to reduce the ready availability of these drugs, particularly anabolic steroids, on the black market. The recommendations of this report flow from the inescapable conclusion that the use of performance enhancing drugs by sports people in Australia is widespread and is accepted as normal practice among some groups. This is a matter of considerable concern because of the serious health risks, often long term, associated with their use. Many of these do not appear until several years after the drugs have been taken. These effects are often not known or understood by the athletes using the drugs. Moreover, it is not always appreciated that the behavioural changes caused by some of these drugs, particularly some of the stimulants and the anabolic steroids, can result in a lack of judgment and increased aggression and that they may cause the persons taking them to become a danger to their fellow competitors.

SPEECH.PARA: In recommending actions intended to make it more difficult for Australian athletes to use performance enhancing drugs, the Committee is aware that a stringent drug testing regime for Australian sports people, if not accompanied by similar regimes in other countries, would reduce the international competitiveness of Australian sports people. However, in the Committee's view the health and injury risks associated with drugs used for performance enhancement are such that their use for this purpose must be prevented. Other countries should be encouraged to adopt the strict approach outlined in this report. The Committee is confident that the Australian Olympic Federation will accept the recommendations relating to the establishment of a completely independent drug testing commission and associated appeals body. The Committee hopes and has recommended that Mr Kevan Gosper, President of the Australian Olympic Federation, should use his influence to encourage other countries to establish similar and equally stringent procedures.

This interim report then falls into two parts. The first four chapters are concerned with general issues relating to the drugs being used, the extent to which they are being used, why they are being used, drug testing, and various matters relating to the supply of drugs. The second part of the report provides a detailed analysis of matters relating to the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS). As I have said already, the evidence demonstrates a widespread use and acceptance of performance enhancing drugs. These substances are used in virtually all sports, at all levels, and by both amateur and professional sports people. They are even used by children, in some cases with the encouragement of their parents. Drug abuse is more prevalent in some sports than in others. Weight-lifting and power-lifting are two examples of sports in which the use of anabolic steroids is widespread and in which an athlete is unlikely to be internationally competitive without their use.

Athletes are under intense pressure to perform. This pressure is not just something which they generate themselves, but is a result of community expectations, media coverage and, not least, the attitudes of their coaches and sports administrators who themselves are under considerable pressure. In using every means available to enhance their performance it is not surprising that some athletes are tempted or persuaded to use pharmacological aids, particularly given that normal practice often involves the consumption of large numbers of vitamins and other food supplements. A few extra pills may not seem to be any different, but, unfortunately, this is not the case. To illustrate the ease with which these substances can be obtained, I will quote directly from a letter from SAA Research, a company that has a post office box address in North Beach, Western Australia. It states:
Dear Sir Madam,
Thank you for your inquiry towards the availability of steroids in Australia.

If you have tried your doctor or a vet with little success we suggest you go to a gym where body builders or athletes frequent and ask the gym owner or instructor. They will be aware of a source of supply. We suggest you ask them for the name of a doctor or some-one who can fill your request. If you are positive you want to use steroids you will find no difficulty in approaching these people. If you hold any reserve at all maybe you should forget the whole idea of taking steroids. It takes more reserve to take them than to ask for them.

We have enclosed a price list you may use as a guideline so you don't get ripped off on the black market. You should also consider using the high quality supplements advertised in the booklet this will ensure a better result with your steroid course.
We hope that when you acquire the steroids you need that you will use them with care and respect for your body.
Yours in health
George Farquhar
S.A.A. Research Secretary
A book entitled For the proper use and understanding of Anabolic Steroids in Australian Sports (updated) has the following paragraph on its last page:
WANTED

SAA Research would like to hear from people interested in becoming distributors for our supplements and this publication. If you are a gym owner, athletic coach or football coach, or just somebody interested in a little extra income from your friends at the gym or club.
Please write to us at the above address for a special distributors price list and include a stamp so we can return your inquiry.

As discussed in the report, many athletes are using veterinary anabolic steroids because they are just as effective and much cheaper than those designed for human use. As I will mention later, the Committee has made recommendations to help stop this problem.

The best deterrent to the use of performance enhancing drugs is an effective drug testing program. The report describes the many deficiencies in existing testing programs and has recommended that a completely independent Australian Sports Drug Commission be established to take over the responsibility of developing sports drug policies and to conduct all aspects of all sports drug testing in Australia. The Commission should report the results of drug tests to the appropriate sporting federations for action but should itself prepare an annual report, to be tabled in parliament, listing all of the results and providing comment on anomalous results. For reasons detailed in the interim report, the Commission should conduct a minimum of 2,000 tests a year using a mixture of random, targeted and competition testing. In addition, tests should also be carried out for professional sporting organisations on a full cost-recovery basis. At the same time as the Commission is established, an independent tribunal should be appointed to adjudicate on disputed drug tests and the penalties being imposed. This tribunal should hear appeals from the Commission, the sporting federations and individual athletes.

A basis for the model proposed already exists in the organisation established in February of this year to take responsibility for the testing and associated appeals to be conducted by the Australian Commonwealth Games Organisation. This consists of a selection panel and an appeals tribunal. The membership of the selection panel would be Dr Brian Corrigan, Chairman, presently the Chairman of the Committee of the National Program on Drugs in Sport; Dr Ken Fitch, Deputy Chairman; and Mr Steve Haynes, Manager, presently manager of the national program on drugs in sport. The appeals tribunal comprises: Dr Ken Donald, Chairman, Deputy Director-General of Health and Medical Services, Queensland Department of Health; Mr Hayden Opie, a lecturer in law at the University of Melbourne; Ms Elaine Canty, a sports broadcaster and lawyer; and Ms Julie Draper, a co-ordinator of the national sports research program.

I view with extreme concern pressure which is now building up within the Commonwealth Games Association since the preparation of these recommendations for the testing in the lead-up to the next Commonwealth Games in Auckland in 1990 to be taken away from the drugs in sport program and the above bodies and placed under the control of, amongst others, Dr David Kennedy, from the Australian Weightlifting Federation. The Committee heard evidence that a weight-lifter was tested by Dr David Kennedy at the 1987 Moomba weight-lifting competition and was found to be negative for drugs. At that same time the weight-lifter was ingesting by his own admission up to 32.5 milligrams a day of Lonovar, an anabolic steroid, and receiving additional injections of Sustanon, a synthetic testosterone. The Committee intends to investigate how it is possible to test negative whilst taking this volume of anabolic steroids and testosterone, and I hope it is not necessary to conduct a parallel investigation into the Australian testing procedures leading up to the 1990 Auckland Games.

The Committee has also recommended that a meeting be convened of all Commonwealth and State Ministers responsible for sport and health matters and that this meeting should adopt a definition of doping to be accepted by every sporting organisation receiving public funding; develop appropriate funding and charging policies for the proposed Australian Sports Drug Commission; agree that a fixed proportion of all public moneys allocated for sports funding be directed to the Australian Sports Drug Commission for testing and other programs; set standard penalties to be adopted by sporting bodies for offences relating to the use of performance enhancing drugs; make the supply of veterinary anabolic steroids for human use an offence; make anabolic steroids prepared for human use a schedule 8 drug; and finally, develop a uniform licensing system for gymnasiums and health centres in Australia with a requirement being that anabolic steroids and other drugs not be available, admitted, or used on the premises. These measures, with others recommended in the report, should serve to restrict the use and availability in Australia of performance enhancing drugs, particularly anabolic steroids, which are the most commonly abused drugs at present.

The second part of the report is concerned with matters relating to the Australian Institute of Sport. The Institute has been very proud of its random drug testing program and has argued to the Committee that the existence of this program has shown that performance enhancing drugs have not been used there. The analysis of the AIS drug testing program presented in chapter 11 of this interim report shows, however, that the program can be given no credibility at all. The selection and testing procedures were carried out in such a careless way that no action could have been taken if any athlete had tested positive. For example, the AIS drug testing files showed that four athletes were drug tested several days before they were actually selected for their respective tests. A charitable view of this general approach is that it seems to have been one of having a drug testing program for appearances sake, with little worry paid to its effectiveness. The nurse responsible for collecting the test samples was never given proper supervision and even the person in direct charge of the program, Dr Peter Fricker, did not seem to be concerned about keeping the necessary documentation. Without this proper documentation the whole program was worthless. Of the 99 specimen identification forms examined by the Committee, for example, only 10 had a signature from both a chaperone and area supervisor, as required by the testing protocol. Two of these, it is worth noting, had been supervised by the replacement nurse, not by the person normally responsible for conducting the tests. The ineffectiveness of the AIS drug testing procedures is demonstrated by the fact that athletes formerly at the Institute have admitted that they were taking banned substances while there. Moreover, two athletes, while scholarship holders at the Institute, were, with the full agreement of the administration, given anabolic steroids for medical reasons, in one case to speed up recovery to allow him to compete. The sensitivity of this matter is recognised by the doctor concerned, who went to exceptional lengths to ensure that no written record of what was happening was kept on official files. Instead he kept separate records, which he afterwards personally destroyed.

Despite the investigation undertaken by my Committee into the medical practices at the AIS, I was alarmed to be informed recently that a Dr R. A. Reid indicated on Institute letterhead that he was providing oral cortico-steroids to an athlete on 17 March 1989. This is in clear breach of the International Olympic Committee guidelines and I am at a compete loss to understand why, after such an intensive inquiry by my Committee, the AIS medical staff have still not resolved to adhere to IOC guidelines on banned sporting drugs.

The report provides an analysis of the attitude and response of the administration of the AIS to the very serious public allegations that were made concerning drug use at the Institute. The Committee has concluded that the response of the administration to these allegations was inadequate. The Institute's solicitors conducted an inquiry following allegations made in a Four Corners program in November 1987 and after writs had been served on the Australian Institute of Sport by three weight-lifters, alleging that they had been administered anabolic steroids while they were scholarship holders at the Institute. Although the Australian Institute of Sport Board received a verbal briefing from the solicitors on the inquiry, the full written report was not requested by anyone associated with the Institute until this Committee requested a copy. The solicitors' report raised matters which, in our view, required further examination. Indeed, in the case of the weight-lifting squad at the Institute, significant problems seem to have existed which were ignored.

The most serious allegations concerning drug use at the Australian Institute of Sport were made about the weight-lifting area, and involved the head coach of weight-lifting, Mr Lyn Jones. A large part of the Committee's efforts have gone into examining these allegations. The Committee has concluded that Mr Jones was less than truthful in the evidence that he gave to the Committee, and that his knowledge of performance enhancing drugs was much greater than he was prepared to admit. There is no doubt that anabolic steroids were being used at the Australian Institute of Sport weight-lifting unit and that a trade in these drugs was taking place within the unit and to other athletes. These allegations were made not only against Mr Jones, but also by Mr Jones and his supporters against his accusers who were former AIS weight-lifters. Irrespective of the arguments accepted by the Committee, both sides agreed drugs were being used and bought and sold by weight-lifters for a period going back to 1982. This practice and its associated trade were allowed to flourish from 1982 until the Four Corners program of November 1987. By his own admission Mr Jones did not seek to inform the relevant authorities of his certain knowledge that one weight-lifter had taken anabolic steroids in 1983-84 and had competed while doing so. He took no action until November 1987 on his suspicions that two other of his weight-lifters may have been purchasing banned drugs overseas in 1982.

On the basis of the evidence presented to it, the Committee has concluded that Mr Jones supplied and administered anabolic steroids and other banned substances to athletes at the AIS and believes that these drugs could have been purchased using public moneys. A detailed examination of the financial management practices of the AIS has confirmed that control weaknesses existed which could have been exploited by unscrupulous persons to purchase these banned substances. The Institute is already tightening up these procedures to ensure stricter control and accountability, so that the identified weaknesses will be removed. It is possible that to some extent protection within the financial administration of the Institute must have been afforded to Mr Jones to enable him to fund purchases of these drugs and to obtain supplies from within Australia and overseas.

The Committee accepted the view of Mr Don Talbot that he was opposed to the use of sporting drugs and his statement was supported by his actions whilst Director of the Australian Institute of Sport. Of the other two officers able to protect Mr Jones-Mr Peter Bowman and Mr John Scarano-the Committee found Mr Scarano to be an honest and efficient officer. In relation to Mr Bowman the Committee made only one recommendation relating to the Australian Institute of Sport and that was that an investigation be held into the purchase of medical supplies without medical authorisation. The Committee also believes that it is possible that Mr Jones imported banned substances into Australia and that he used members of his weight-lifting squad to assist him. When considering the motives for Mr Jones's actions it should be realised that all sports involve a combination of both strength and skill. In sports such as weight-lifting and power-lifting, the emphasis is very much on strength. The Committee has received information from many sports medicine practitioners and persons experienced in power-lifting and weight-lifting on the effects of anabolic steroids. When used in medically unsafe doses, steroids can cause increases in strength of around 30 per cent.

Mr Chris Turner, Secretary of the Australian Drug Free Powerlifting Federation, stated to the Committee that there was a 30 per cent increase in performance in the Australian Powerlifting Association compared with his drug free association. If sporting drugs such as anabolic steroids can increase strength by as much as 30 per cent, and as the difference between first and last in a major international event may be only one or two per cent, it is clear that coaches in strength sports are confronted with a straight forward decision: to reject drugs and lose or seek to exploit drugs more effectively than their fellow coaches and win at the risk of disqualification. In view of the negligible risk of detection and disqualification under the drug testing at the AIS and in Australian weight-lifting under Dr Fricker and Dr Kennedy respectively, the Committee formed the view that this latter alternative was the approach adopted by both Mr Lyn Jones and his assistant Mr Harry Wardle. It should be pointed out that Mr Lyn Jones is no longer employed at the Institute, his contract not being renewed after it expired in December 1988. Mr Harry Wardle remains at the Institute as a strength coach despite the conclusions of the AIS solicitors in their post-Four Corners report, a report which I presume has since been shown in full to the new AIS Board.

It should be emphasised here that if Australian weight-lifting follows the drug free path, it will not be possible for Australia to have any internationally competitive weight-lifting squad until honest and updated testing arrangements are put in place around the world. One of the areas that will be looked at closely by the Committee is the role played by weight-lifting and power-lifting in other sports, because of the extensive use of weight training across a wide range of sports. Weight-lifting and power-lifting are both sports that are drug dependent as far as current international and national competitions are concerned. The Committee will have to consider whether or not to recommend to the Government and the Australian Olympic Federation that weight-lifting remain as an Olympic sport. It is clear that weight-lifting and weight-lifters play a large role in the use and supply of performance enhancing drugs, particularly anabolic steroids, to competitors from other sports who share the same facilities. I also note in passing that attempts by the Drug Free Powerlifting Association to clean up its sport have recently been hindered by moves from the Australian Amateur Powerlifting Federation itself to register the Drug Free Powerlifting name. This will be subject to further investigation by the Committee.

Specific allegations concerning the purchase and supply of drugs had also been made against two track and field coaches at the Australian Institute of Sport, Mr Merv Kemp and Mr Craig Hilliard. The Committee was unable to substantiate these allegations and reached no conclusions about whether the alleged incidents had taken place, but noted that on a number of occasions Mr Kemp had taken actions in an attempt to ensure that deficiencies in existing drug testing procedures were remedied. A matter of great concern to the Committee was that AIS track and field coaches did not take action when confronted with evidence that athletes either were taking anabolic steroids or had been involved in an attempt to interfere with a drug test. The report describes in detail an incident in Belfast in 1986 in which an Australian official and an athlete at the AIS attempted to substitute a clean urine sample for one from an athlete that they thought might test positive. A number of coaches at the Institute were aware of this attempted interference but did not inform the AIS administration of what had happened. The Committee has also concluded that Dr Ken Maguire, while employed by the Institute, ignored his responsibilities to the Australia Institute of Sport by not passing on information that a track and field athlete was taking a banned substance. In fact, he arranged a clearance-time test for this athlete so that she could determine how long before a competition she would need to stop taking a substance and still test negative.

In short, the Committee found that many areas of the Australian Institute of Sport have been unsatisfactory, in terms of its handling of matters relating to the use of performance enhancing drugs. Clearly, some further actions are still required following this report. However, the Committee is of the firm view that the establishment of an Australian Sports Drug Commission, as recommended in the report, together with the follow-up actions referred to, will mean that, no matter what has happened in the past, the Institute can be given a clean bill of health so far as the future is concerned. These follow-up actions will be monitored during the second stage of the inquiry. As this is an interim report, the Committee will continue to gather information on the health risks associated with sporting drugs and will be taking evidence from people who have themselves experienced some of the serious side effects of these substances. We will be conducting detailed investigations into high risk sports such as weight-lifting and power-lifting. The Committee will also start its examination of professional sports, although this may be truncated, depending upon the willingness of these sports to subject themselves to the scrutiny of the proposed Australian Sports Drug Commission and its associated appeals body. For example, the New South Wales Rugby League is a major professional sport which has already gone some way down this track towards independent testing. We will also be continuing with our detailed examination of the black market, which is currently the major source of supply of performance enhancing drugs.

The recommendations made in this interim report should be implemented as soon as possible. Without urgent action it is clear that persons with a vested interest in the sports drug market will increase their existing control of some sports. For this reason the Committee will not be particularly sympathetic to any bureaucratic impediments which may be contrived to frustrate or delay the establishment of a truly independent Australian Sports Drugs Commission, a body which will place Australia in the forefront of a world campaign against drug abuse in sport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some comments about the Interim Report of the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled Drugs in Sport. To the extent that the report runs over 500 pages, it is not easy to summarise the deliberations and recommendations of the Committee in 30 minutes. It is inevitable that I retrace some of the ground covered by Senator Black. From the outset, I record Senator Black's personal contribution and dedication to this Committee and his diligence in pursuing the terms of reference. He ensured that we had appropriate and suitable evidence and witnesses.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has been subject to some criticism. If time allows me I will also deal with that. Not the least of that criticism came from two Premiers who, if one takes a moment to think about it, have very good reasons for criticising any Senate standing committee likely to provide information to the Senate. In relation to the Australian Olympic Federation (AOF), I do not want to be emotive about its criticism but if one reads the report and if one were less than generous one could draw some conclusions as to why it, as well as I, have criticised the Committee. I am sorry that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) is not at the table. If he were I would say that it does not reflect generously on the Government that it has taken virtually a month for this report to be tabled in this Parliament.

I will now turn to the heart of the report. As Senator Black has said, it is an interim report. That is why I raise the matter of the Government's involvement. In the view of the Committee it was important that we have an interim report because it deals with some fundamental and consequential matters touching upon the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS). We felt it important that that part of the Committee's deliberations be tabled as quickly as possible. The evidence demonstrates that drugs, particularly anabolic steroids, have been readily available and readily dispensed at the Australian Institute of Sport, particularly amongst weight-lifters. The evidence leads inexorably to the conclusion that Mr Lyn Jones, the head coach of the weight-lifting division, regularly and consistently provided his lifters with anabolic steroids. The drugs were purchased both in Australia and overseas by Mr Jones and, in my view, his athletes.

On the basis of evidence provided to the Committee it is my view that Mr Jones was not the only coach to provide performance enhancing drugs to his athletes. At the very least, other coaches knew of drug taking and did absolutely nothing about it. For instance, Mr Kemp was well aware that Gael Martin was taking drugs when a scholarship holder at the AIS and he did absolutely nothing about it. Mr Hilliard had reason to believe that one of his athletes, Mr David Smith, was using banned drugs and did nothing about it. Mr Kelvin Giles, previously head coach, track and field, was well aware that one of his athletes, Sue Howland, when using AIS facilities was using anabolic steroids and did nothing about it.

Mr Kemp, Mr Giles, Mr Hilliard, Mr Rice, the head coach of track and field at the AIS, and Mr Bowman, then coordinator, track and field, at the AIS, were all aware that Ms Jane Flemming, a scholarship holder at the AIS, had provided a urine sample to Mr Maurie Plant, an official of the Australian Athletics Union (AAU), at his request, for his stated purpose of substituting a urine test sample for Sue Howland in June 1986 at a pre-Commonwealth Games meeting in Belfast. Mr Kemp wrote to the Australian Athletics Union, for whatever reason, but like the others he did nothing to inform the AIS administration. To this day no action has been taken by either the AIS or the AAU. Evidence provided to the Committee demonstrates that Ms Howland provided her own sample which ultimately tested negative.

I have no doubt that both Dr Fricker and Dr Maguire well knew of drug use at the AIS. In my view, it would be quite impossible for them not to have known. Dr Maguire gave evidence of his knowledge of Sue Howland's drug use and Dr Fricker gave evidence of his knowledge of Gael Martin's drug use. But I believe that both have a much wider knowledge. Frankly, it is improbable that Sister Beasley was not aware of drug use at the Institute. It is clear to me that Dr Maguire ordered testing at Ms Sue Howland's request for the purpose of giving her knowledge as to when she would cease her steroid schedule so as not to test positive. Page 446 of the report states:

The Committee concludes that the medical reasons advanced for ordering the testosterone to epitestosterone ratio by Dr Maguire are not convincing and are contradictory to evidence from other medical experts. Similarly, his discussion of the testosterone level results did not contribute to the Committee's understanding of his purpose in ordering the tests in the form that he did. The most telling evidence is that the results were apparently not used in any subsequent consultation.

Ms Howland's evidence, in contrast, is consistent and easily understood. In wishing to establish the clearance times for Andriol, she sought to have the same test as used in a drug test taken before, during and after a course on Andriol. She would have no reason to be concerned about the androgenic effects of Andriol (a testosterone) because she would use an anabolic steroid during training and only change to testosterone for a short period nearer to a drug-tested competition. She obtained the results subsequently from Macquarie Pathology without Dr Maguire's assistance and the results of the testosterone test are consistent with her explanation.

The Committee concludes that Dr Maguire arranged the testosterone tests for Ms Howland for the purpose of establishing her clearance time for Andriol and that this was done at public expense. Mr Giles is implicated with this action to mislead the Committee. Ms Howland's evidence is judged to be a consistent and true account of events.

I now turn to testing at the Institute. Due no doubt in large part to the very considerable costs, drug testing at the Institute has been on a comparatively small scale. At 30 June 1988 there were 294 athletes on scholarships at the Institute with a testing rate of one or two athletes a week. It is now two. An athlete could expect to be tested about once every three or six years-hardly a disincentive to drug taking. Of more concern is the manner in which the testing has been conducted. The testing requires three people to sign the specimen identification form, one of whom is the area supervisor, who is responsible for ensuring that the sample is properly collected and sealed so it cannot be tampered with. For very obvious reasons, the area supervisor must be identified on the form. A chaperone-obviously of the same sex as the athlete, one would assume-is required to witness the urine collection to ensure that the urine collected in the bottle was passed by the athlete. Again, the chaperone's name must be identified on the form as a witness. Finally, the athlete is required to sign the form confirming that these events took place. I direct the Senate's attention to page 467 of the report which states:

Of the 99 Specimen Identification Forms on the AIS file provided to the Committee, only 10 contain the signature of both a chaperone and an area supervisor in accord with accepted procedures. Two of these 10 were supervised by the replacement nurse. Another two of these 10 tests involved a longer delay between selection for testing and the time of giving a urine sample than the allowed 48 hours. Overall, less than 10 per cent of all tests in 1986 and 1987 met the accepted standards and the Committee believes, as a result, that the integrity during this period of the entire AIS testing program is questionable.

The Committee is saying there that in the event that any of the athletes had tested positive and appealed against that positive test, it is of the view that, under normal circumstances, the appeal would have been upheld. Under those circumstances, it is not unreasonable to draw the conclusion that it was possible for sink testing or for tampering of tests to have taken place. It is not without significance that allegations of sink testing and other tampering were made to the Committee by Mr Hambesis, a weight-lifter, Gael Martin and Sue Howland who were quite precise in the evidence that they provided. I quote from the Committee's determinations:

. . . because of the lack of proper documentation, in many cases there is no evidence that the urine sample was actually provided by the athletes being tested. Even if samples were found positive it is highly unlikely that any action could have been taken when area supervisors or chaperones were not recorded or had not signed the required forms. As discussed later, Dr Fricker himself was party to these lax procedures, quite apart from his overall responsibility for the drug testing program. The comments made above by Dr Fricker about Ms Howland and Mrs Martin's appalling lack of understanding of dope testing are much more appropriately applied to himself, as his statement that International Olympic Committee procedures were used is just not true.

There was other disturbing evidence in respect of testing at the AIS not least the fact that one athlete in particular who was selected for testing was turned away when he presented himself to be tested. The records show that four athletes selected randomly for testing were actually tested before they were selected. One can speculate as to how that happened. Many pass-holders have access to the AIS facilities and they have not been tested. In fact, Dr Maguire gave evidence that he had complained about this to the administration for a very long time, particularly because he had reason to believe that some of the athletes were drug users. At the time of the taking of the evidence nothing had been done to put that right. As from 17 April, as I understand it, testing by the Australian Institute of Sport is to include all those who are facility pass-holders and overseas athletes who, up until this point, have been able, when visiting Australia, to use the facilities and be certain and comforted in the knowledge that they would not be tested.

I now refer to the financial administration of the AIS. The Committee has considered and examined with some care the financial administration of the AIS because of concerns that AIS funds may have been used to purchase performance enhancing drugs. The Committee has not established that to be the case beyond reasonable doubt; however, the system of financial management has in the past made that possible. From my reading of the evidence, it clearly points in that direction. As recently as 1987-88 Price Waterhouse noted two instances when Mr Lyn Jones purchased medical supplies without a doctor's authorisation. I give one example which in my view is symptomatic of the problems of the AIS. One receipt presented by Mr Lyn Jones to the AIS for reimbursement amounted to $90 for the supply of vitamins and food supplements which had not been authorised by medical staff and which was allegedly from a pharmacy operated by Mr Colin Bova in Burwood, New South Wales. The handwritten receipt showed the Bova chemist as being in Victoria. Of course, there is no Bova chemist in Victoria. Bova chemist has denied issuing the receipt.

If one wanted to conjecture, it would not be unreasonable to draw the conclusion that the receipt is a forgery and that the person making out the receipt merely mixed up the States. It is hardly likely that a chemist in New South Wales would write `Victoria' on his own receipt. Mr Peter Bowman was then the Administrator of the AIS. The Committee expressed this view:

. . . Mr Bowman had no personal involvement in the approval of the payment of the $90 receipt, supposedly from Colin Bova Chemist but said by Mr Bova not to be from his pharmacy. Mr Bowman noted that the receipt was for a small amount which had been approved under `a proper delegation' and was more concerned over this than over the fact that public moneys could have been misappropriated.

The committee was more concerned that Mr Bowman had not sought to closely examine the contents of the Price Waterhouse report prior to his appearance before the Committee, given that much of the substance of the report's adverse findings directly related to his activities as the then head of financial administration at the AIS. The Committee finds that Mr Peter Bowman has displayed a disregard for the proper public accountability for the expenditure of public moneys inconsistent with his former position as Company Secretary and Administrator of the AIS.

Price Waterhouse noted two incidences in 1987-88 where Mr Jones had been able to initiate purchases of medical supplies without a doctor's authorisation. These incidents occurred under the administration of the current management team. Chief Executive, Mr Ron Harvey, `was not aware of that'.
Logically, the Committee then recommends:
. . . that the AIS investigate the approval of medical supply purchases without medical officer authorisation, contrary to AIS policy, with a view to disciplinary action.

It is not possible for me to go through all of the findings of the Committee; however, there is one matter that has been noted by the Committee which is of some concern and about which there is a recommendation-that is, the use of animal steroids, particularly by athletes in gymnasiums. We have knowledge of hulking young men asking veterinary suppliers for a dose of steroids for their dad's racehorse. This practice is of great danger to the athletes not only in terms of the quantities supplied but also in terms of the quality of the supplies.

There has been considerable criticism of the AOF for its drug testing from 1 January, not the least being from myself. Mr Gosper's response was to threaten to write to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) seeking to have me removed from the Committee. It shows a good understanding of Senate procedures. It might be how the Australian Olympic Federation deals with critics, and it might be how Shell deals with critics, but it is not the way in which the Parliament conducts its business. It shows an abysmal lack of understanding of parliamentary procedures by Mr Gosper.

There are other criticisms of people such as Dr Millar, Director of Research at the Lewisham Institute of Sports Medicine. His athletes were notified in November 1987 that they were to be randomly tested from 1 July 1988, thus allowing them to cease using anabolic steroids by that time and so avoiding detection while obtaining their full benefits. In other words, the Australian Olympic Federation had given adequate and ample time for those athletes using anabolic steroids to cease using them so as to ensure that at the time of testing those athletes would test clean. It is interesting to note the comments of people such as Darren Clark, the Australian 400-metre champion, who stated:
If it was up to me I would have them go out and test them straight away and get rid of them.
Mr Clark was suggesting that the Australian Olympic Federation should be trying to find the cheats, not quarantine them. The report stated:
Mr Hurst, Mr Clark's coach, went further to suggest that:

I cannot see any reason for taking steroids after Christmas, after New Year, because the selection trials are usually in March and the State titles are in February. That is the testing period; that is the high competition phase. Presumably nobody would take drugs during the competition period, so the time to test them would be in the September to December period.
Mr John Coates, Vice-President of the Australian Olympic Federation, responded to this criticism in part by stating:

We brought in our doping policy on 6 November [1987]-and I am aware this is a criticism from Dr Millar-and we brought in a life ban for the first time. We thought it only proper that we give notice that we would start testing on 1 January. I do not think it would have been the right thing to do by the athletes to have tested the very next day, which would have then resulted in a retrospective doping policy-retrospective by two or three months. As I said, the purpose of a strong doping policy such as ours is the deterrent element. It is not to catch athletes. We want to make it quite clear to athletes that, if they had been taking drugs for sport enhancement, then they stood a very grave risk of being selected by us, and we gave them due warning. I think that was the proper thing to do.
That is the way in which Mr Coates interprets events. The report further states:

Dr Ken Fitch, Chairman of the Medical Commission of the AOF, indicated that `only legal, ethical and logistic factors' necessitated a six week period to make practical arrangements before testing could begin. These arrangements included setting up the tests and requiring National Sports Federations to agree to allow the AOF to test their athletes, obtain lists of potential Olympic athletes and seek their consent to testing.
Dr Fitch's evidence is contradicted by a memorandum from Mr Coles (AOF Secretary-General) to Executive Directors and Secretaries of National Sports Federation in June 1987.

The Committee draws the conclusion-having now learned by its own diligence and not by the generous and willing cooperation of the Australian Olympic Federation-that the athletes had six months notice. The Committee observed:

It is quite clear that potential Olympic athletes were provided with an opportunity to use anabolic steroids during the non-competitive, training phase of September to December in 1987, provided they ceased the use of the steroids in time to avoid detection in a random testing program beginning in January 1988. The performance-enhancing effects of steroids used in this manner would continue, to a diminishing degree, throughout the competitive season of February to April in 1988. In effect, drug-assisted athletes could be assisted to gain selection in the Olympic team over their drug-free competitors, and then perform below their previous standards at the Olympics because of the AOF testing program. Two classes of athletes were created; the drug free athletes who were disadvantaged, and the drug-assisted athletes who gained funding, prestige and selection but who performed poorly at tested international events.

It is also clear that the AOF could have begun a random program in, say, September of 1987, and withheld announcing any test results until May 1988, as indicated in the memorandum. The first of January 1988 was an arbitrary date which did not take into account the practical realities of steroids use.

There were good reasons for not applying for newly announced life bans from the day they were approved on 6 November 1987. However, this was a separate issue from the implementation of the testing program which was foreshadowed six months earlier. A life ban might only have applied from 1 January 1988, even if a random testing program had been operable since September 1987.
The Committee concludes:

Considering the extensive questioning of the AOF about the six weeks notice given to athletes that testing would begin, and the defensive position adopted by the AOF, the Committee views with concern the fact that six months notice was given and that AOF officials were aware of this when giving evidence. It is absurd that the Committee only found out about the six months notice through a routine request for the minutes of a relevant meeting. The Committee views the attitude and conflicting evidence of the AOF with scepticism, and can only conclude that the prime consideration of the program was not to prevent drug use but to allow affected athletes to pass drug tests during selection trials.

I can imagine why Mr Gosper is not happy with me. The Committee will continue to take evidence and to pursue its inquiries. In the few minutes I have left I make the point that the community as a whole has done very little, in terms of its considerations, its debates and its deliberations, about the use of performance enhancing drugs by athletes in Australia, not only at the elite level but also by casual weekend athletes and, sadly, by young children. In this day and age there are enormous social pressures on Australian athletes to use drugs. As we all know, Australians do not tolerate failures lightly. Athletes returning from the Olympic Games who are unsuccessful can expect perhaps a polite nod and a small clap. We seem to love the winners but we dismiss the losers ever so quickly. I continue to be reminded of Stephen Holland in 1976 coming back from Montreal, where he smashed his own world record but achieved a bronze medal. He came third. When he got off the aeroplane he was asked why he had failed and the media wrote him off as a failure.

What pressure is society putting on these athletes? That is the very reason we now have the Australian Institute of Sport. In the 1976 Montreal Games and the 1978 Edmonton Games Australian athletes did not achieve the level of success that was expected of them. We had too many losers and not enough winners. We had to do something about it so that we could again feel proud and stand in the reflected glory of our athletes; so that we could be proud to be Aussies, cheering from the comfortable position of a lounge room chair with a tinny in our hand and the television heated up. We ask ourselves: Why is it that athletes attempt to take performance enhancing drugs? We have only to look at the worldwide competitive pressures on our elite athletes.

The Committee had evidence from one young lady who was lined up for a 400-metre event in one of the eastern European countries. In her words, she felt as though she were competing against men. The women had all the physical attributes of men: they had deep voices, Adam's apples, enormous thigh muscles and muscle mass generally, acne and all the traits that one would find as a result of the use of anabolic steroids. In fact, one athlete told us unofficially that she was rooming with a girl who used to have a shave every morning when she got up. Our drug-free athletes are expected to bring home gold medals after competing around the world against other athletes, who in some cases are given drugs by their coaches with the endorsement of their countries and, in other cases, are given drugs frivolously and freely by their coaches and those who support them.

We have only to look at the financial rewards involved these days. I think Senator Black observed in his comments that the difference between gold and glory and failure and obscurity can be but a part of a second in a hundred metres. The difference between Ben Johnson winning and coming fourth was but part of a second. If he had come fourth he would have received no financial reward. If he had come first and his use of anabolic steroids had not been detected he would have been the beneficiary of in the range of $16m-for but part of a second. When our drug-free athletes see other athletes being administered anabolic steroids in careful and controlled doses under the supervision of doctors, assured by the best of medical advice that there will be no medium to long term effects, there is an enormous temptation for Australian athletes to say, `Why do we not at least try to compete on the same playing field?'. The difference between getting the glory and winning a gold medal for their country or coming home in obscurity can be but part of a second, so there is a temptation for them to be like everybody else.

Perhaps one of the problems that confront us all is that there is no proper and enlightened understanding of the effects that these drugs can have on our athletes. There is a great need in Australia not only for that education but also for an indication of the temptations to which athletes are subjected to take performance enhancing drugs. We talk about an even playing field as the excuse for not using them; yet if we compare the advantages of athletes in advanced economies with athletes in Third World economies we can see that there is no even playing field. There is an enormous gulf between the advantages given to one athlete and the advantages given to others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, relates to the veterans aspects of these four Bills now before the Senate. Senator Powell will address the Democrats' concerns about the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. My comments will be confined to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, which effects what are described as certain minor amendments to relevant legislation and provides repatriation benefits to service personnel joining the United Nations Transition Assistance Group in Namibia.

SPEECH.PARA: We have particular concerns about this Bill. The Australian Democrats' attitude to this veterans legislation has been strongly influenced by the case of Beryl Ann Bagshaw Farrow. Beryl Ann Bagshaw Farrow was born in 1919 in Richmond, Surrey, in the United Kingdom. In March 1939, when she was 20 years old, she joined the auxiliary territorial services as a driver. Until February 1941 her duties were mainly clerical, but in that month she was posted to a training centre which trained personnel to drive ambulances. She was instructed in first aid and motor mechanics. During the next three years she served as an ambulance driver at various locations in south-east England. She worked very long hours in extremely difficult and dangerous circumstances. As a part of her work, Beryl Farrow was subjected to air attacks and operated in areas which were being bombed continually. In June 1944 she was transferred to London, where she drove six-ton lorries, delivering mail and supplies. Between June 1944 and early 1945 she had to change her billet four times because of bomb damage to the houses where she had been living. She was instructed that in the event of air raid warning, she was to keep driving until she saw the bombs falling, and only then to take cover. Beryl Farrow was demobilised in November 1945. She came to live permanently in Australia in 1948 and was granted Australian citizenship in May 1973.

I relate the story of Beryl Farrow because her circumstances alerted us to a problem with part of this Bill. For her service to her country, Beryl Farrow was awarded the War Medal, the British Defence Medal, the Efficiency Medal and the King's Badge. When she felt it appropriate, Beryl Farrow applied for a service pension. Under the provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 a veteran must prove service as defined in section 36 of the Act. That section states that, for the purposes of the Act, a person must have:
established . . . service within that country, being service in respect of which the person has been awarded, or has become eligible to be awarded, a campaign medal;

Beryl Farrow believed her British Defence Medal to be a campaign medal as it was something she was awarded for her active service in the protection of her country. But she was denied the service pension. The Department of Veterans' Affairs claimed that the British Defence Medal was not a campaign medal for the purposes of eligibility for a service pension. Beryl Farrow took her case to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for its ruling in this matter. None of the facts in this case was disputed, but the contentious issue was the definition of a campaign medal. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal ruled that her Defence Medal was a campaign medal. Its report, dated 9 February 1989, ruled that a campaign, according to the Shorter Oxford Dictionary, was:
a continuous series of military operations, constituting the whole, or a distinct part, of a war.

The Administrative Appeals Tribunal found that operational air crews, such as those which took part in the Battle of Britain or the bombing missions flown from bases in England and Europe, were actively involved in a military campaign. The Tribunal took the view that not only the aggressors but the defenders on the ground were participants in the campaign. It found that the defence of the United Kingdom was a distinct and well defined part of the military campaign. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal ruled that the award of the Defence Medal for participation in the defence of the United Kingdom was a medal in respect of service in a campaign and therefore represented the award of a campaign medal.

The Commonwealth was found to be liable to pay the service pension to Beryl Ann Farrow, the payments to be backdated to 23 February 1987. Clause 11 (c) of this Bill seeks to define a campaign medal. It states:
`campaign medal', in relation to service during the period of World War 2 from its commencement to and including 29 October 1945, means:
(a) any of the following medals:
(ii) Atlantic Star;
(iii) Air Crew Europe Star;
(iv) Africa Star;
(v) Pacific Star;
(vi) Burma Star;
(vii) Italy Star;
(viii) France and Germany Star; or
(b) any other medal declared by the regulations to be a campaign medal in relation to service during that period.''.

The reason the Government is proposing this clause is to tighten the eligibility of veterans for the service pension. The term `campaign medal' was not defined in the Veterans' Entitlements Act of 1986. The Beryl Farrow case has effectively pointed out something that the Department had previously overlooked. It is no surprise that the British Defence Medal is not included in the list of campaign medals; this is despite the Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision that it is a campaign medal.

The Australian Democrats' concern is that, although the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has ruled that recipients of the British Defence Medal are eligible for a service pension, this clause tries to cut them out of what we believe to be their right, and what the Administrative Appeals Tribunal believes to be their right. For this reason, we propose that clause 11 (c) of the Bill be deleted. I will move an amendment, hopefully to achieve that effect, in the committee stage.

The Veterans' Affairs Department, in its arguments to the Tribunal, claimed that, even though Beryl Farrow's war service was highly meritorious, people who had done very little for their country could also have received the Defence Medal. One should not disqualify one applicant who qualifies for the service pension simply because there may be a hypothetical recipient who does not deserve one. It is interesting that the Department has not appealed against the Administrative Appeals Tribunal ruling. As I have said, at the committee stage the Democrats will move an amendment to delete that clause which seeks to deprive other people like Beryl Ann Farrow of their entitlements. We consider this to be unjust and inappropriate.

It is not known just how many recipients of the Defence Medal are still alive. The British Government claims to have dispersed all of its records of those who were awarded this honour. The Returned Services League of Australia has approached us to amend this Bill in the manner I have explained because it feels, as does the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, that it is not fair or just to deprive one person of the benefit of a service pension just because a person not deserving of the pension could receive one. Who decides whether a person is or is not deserving of one?

The Government's amendment seems to be another event in the practice of recent years of so tightening eligibility under the Veterans' Entitlements Act that in some cases deserving persons, such as Beryl Farrow, will not be eligible. Other persons equally deserving of the service pension could be prevented from receiving it if this clause goes through as the Government plans.

Of course, we do not support the delaying of the Bill or preventing its passage through the Parliament, because of the urgency of the amendments affecting members of the Australian Defence Force currently serving this country in Namibia. We are disappointed that the Opposition has indicated that it will not support the deletion of clause 11 (c). Therefore, we believe the Opposition will support the Government in passing legislation which may well give rise to very significant injustice and which is in contravention of the appeals mechanism. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal has ruled in favour of this pertinent case and the benchmark has been established.

We are equally disappointed that yet again, in the final analysis, the Opposition has gone soft on veterans' issues and has failed to support Democrats' amendments designed to deliver to the veteran community what they believe to be their just entitlements. I can cite at least seven cases in the last 18 months where the Opposition has voted with the Government to deprive veterans of what they consider their just entitlements. It is not surprising that members of the veterans' community have become very angry, particularly with the position taken by the Government and the Minister in relation to their entitlements. It is not surprising that, despite the assurances offered by Mr Tim Fischer in the other place and at public meetings, they are increasingly doubting the Opposition's challenge to the position of the Government when it has proved its support for the Government's position on a number of extremely significant occasions.

We have given notice that if the Opposition, in conjunction with the Government, defeats this Democrat amendment we will move a contingency amendment which varies the date of implementation. That amendment was introduced in the lower House by the Opposition itself, yet I am advised that it will oppose it here today. Yet again we find it difficult to come to grips with what is purported to be the logic behind the Opposition's action when it proposes an amendment in the other place but fails to support that same amendment in this place. In the same way, we found it difficult to come to grips with the Opposition's logic in relation to the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill when it moved, as a second reading attachment, the Democrats' amendments to that Bill but minutes later failed to support them in the committee stage. Our contention is that the veterans and service communities are quite capable of reading through the hypocrisy and inconsistencies which the Opposition particularly is displaying in relation to these matters. The Australian Democrats have no further objections to this Bill other than that which I have outlined in relation to clause 11(c). It is not my intention to delay further the passage of these Bills. As I said, I will move those two amendments in the committee stage of the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill and the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill amend the Veterans' Entitlements Act, the Defence Service Homes Act and the Australian War Memorial Act. The very important amendments, which it appears were not seriously addressed by Senator McLean, relate to the servicemen who are serving with the United Nations Transition Assistance Group (UNTAG) in Namibia and will now enable them to have full repatriation cover and defence service home loan eligibility. There are also some technical administrative adjustments which deal with realigning the Australian War Memorial Council and other Commonwealth statutory bodies in relation to their powers to make investments without ministerial approval. They also include an amendment to exclude from the definition of `income' under the income test for service pensions the restitution made by the Federal Republic of Germany to victims of Nazi persecution. The Bills also include an amendment to clarify the Repatriation Commission's power to set charges for treatment provided to community patients in repatriation hospitals, and provide remedies for anomalies in relation to a deceased claimant's legal personal representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: According to Senator McLean, the Bills provide for an adjustment to the criteria for entitlement to the service pension. In this place we are all very aware of the special pleading that the Australian Democrats produce on occasions such as this to convince-they hope-the Australian community that their hearts bleed more than anybody else's for the veterans' community, the pensioner community or whoever is the cause of the day. We had that last week with the nursing mothers and tax deductability. We are having it at the moment with home birthing and midwives. Another current cause is Commonwealth ex-service men and women who have not seen dangerous service. They have not faced danger, but it would appear, according to Senator McLean, that they expect a greater degree of care than we are prepared to give to our own Australian service men and women. That is another matter which I will also address when we come to the committee stage of the Bill.

I want to particularly address the amendments that relate to our men in Namibia. For me, those happen to be the most significant amendments in the legislation. They relate to the repatriation benefits for our soldiers serving with UNTAG in Namibia. Schedule 2 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act will classify the Namibia area as `operational', and all those who serve there will therefore be entitled to full repatriation benefits, medical and financial. Before the Government congratulates itself on its promptness and generosity in this matter, let us have a look at the real record of events. These men in Namibia are facing an extremely dangerous situation. The ceasefire, the South African withdrawal and the withdrawal of the South West Africa People's Organisation guerillas was not smooth. We have already had some armed clashes. We have had political difficulties between the parties in which some of our soldiers have been inadvertently caught up. There are unplotted minefields on the Angolan border and throughout the northern part of Namibia. In his speech in Parliament, Minister Beazley admitted the likelihood of casualties. He said:
. . . the ADF and the Government accept that there may be casualties among our contingent.

I understand that the Army fears quite a serious percentage of likely casualties. These dangers and the possible consequences for the men and their families mean that they need to have the security of knowing that the benefits and compensation are already in place.

We should not forget that this Australian commitment to Namibia was pledged by the Fraser Government in 1978. Australia and the Australian bureaucracy have known about this commitment for more than 10 years. Yet it is only now, three months after the first contingent has left our shores, that we see the legislation which puts those conditions of service and repatriation benefits legally in place. With all the planning that went on, even down to the colour that the vehicles would be painted, I would have expected this legislation to have been sitting there ready to be dusted off and brought to the Parliament so that when the men went they knew exactly what the situation was. It was already well known to the Government that this legislation would have bipartisan support, but it was not in place when the contingent left.

Let it not be forgotten that there is another force of men serving unsung and unhonoured overseas in a peacekeeping force. It is in a debate such as this that I hope this Parliament will remember them. I am referring to the men on the Iran-Iraq border in the United Nations Iran-Iraq Military Observer Group (UNIIMOG). After initial delays in finalising the disability allowance package for these men, I pressured the Government. Three months after the 15 men had left with very little notice-they went within a week of being told to go-the Government promised in the Senate that it would give them the allowances that were necessary for the work that was intended to be done. I draw the attention of the Senate to an answer given by Senator Richardson in the Senate on 29 November 1988. He said:
The intention is that the package of allowances developed to cover service with UNIIMOG be paid while the duty is in progress . . .
He went on to say later in his answer:
Every effort is being made to provide allowances for UNIIMOG members in the shortest time possible . . .

It is now nine months since the first men went to the Iran-Iraq border. The first contingent has now been home for three months. The second contingent has been in place for three months. The danger money for our soldiers on the Iran-Iraq border has still not been finalised. In my questioning of the Department of Defence during the Estimates Committee hearings in April, I received answers which demonstrated that the matter had slipped from high priority in October 1988 to medium priority in April 1989. Clearly, Minister Simmons must learn that honouring the promises of his predecessor is part of his new job. When will we see the danger money being paid? When will it be decided? I remind the Senate that these men on the Iran-Iraq border are Nobel Prize-winners for peace. They are commonly regarded as the finest soldiers that we have. They are unarmed but they face similar dangers to their colleagues in Namibia.

Mr Deputy President, I draw your attention to what some of these dangers are along the Iran-Iraq border. There have been artillery and rocket launcher exchanges. One of them extended over a 50-kilometre front. There have been mine incidents within metres of Australian soldiers. There have been large minefields for which, as in Namibia, there are no maps. There has been extensive flooding in Iran so some of the mines have floated away and relocated. There are unexploded bombs and artillery rounds, including in many areas, we believe, chemical devices which still have not been recovered. Elements of our contingent are under guard at all times by the regime. They have no recreational facilities. Mail may take two to three weeks to arrive at a location, and telephone calls get through only if the Iranian telephone exchange is in the mood-and that rather depends on how the Australian press has reported the Iran situation in our newspapers.

In many ways Australian soldiers in Iran-Iraq are in as difficult a situation as the 300 men we have sent to Namibia. I feel that a case could have been made out to provide them with the allowances and tax free status that apply to our troops in Namibia, but they have not been granted. The Minister, Mr Beazley, seems to think that the fact that the forces are not carrying arms makes the difference. Perhaps those who carry arms might feel themselves to be in a somewhat safer position. While the Government capitalises on Australian soldiers' fame as peacekeepers, it will not produce the money to support them or their families. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) recently answered a question from me by saying that the Department of Defence, in conjunction with the Department of Industrial Relations, is examining recently received data on the difficulties experienced on the Iran-Iraq ceasefire line with a view to assessing the need for further compensation. This Government has had far too much time to assess the need for further compensation. The compensation is danger money and the soldiers have received none of it to this date.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they members of the Defence Force?

—They are members of the Defence Force but clearly are not members of a union. If they were, this Government would listen to them. This Federal Government listens only to unionists. The damage to morale is very serious. Men in Iran-Iraq feel that they are neither recognised nor appreciated for the sacrifices they are making. They feel isolated and shamefully neglected. This attitude has not been restricted to the Iran-Iraq contingent. I believe that the Government's lack of attention to the well-being of the force in Namibia is something for which it should be condemned. When the forces were going away to Namibia on, I think, 3 March the former Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mrs Kelly, sent each man a list of all the conditions of service to which he would be entitled. One of them related to postal assistance. In her statement the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Defence will meet the costs of postage to and from Namibia for both members of the force and their families.

It appears that the Government forgot to tell Australia Post. While our men in Namibia have free postage back to Australia, their families first of all have to pay the Australian postage to get mail to an address from which it is sent off overseas. It is a question of attention to detail. In that area the Government has let the men down.

But, probably more importantly than that, there has been, until now at least, very erratic mail. Australia Post assured me that mail would take four days in each direction plus an allowance for transfer time. But the mail has been always more than seven days late-usually two to three weeks late, and quite often four weeks. Mail has been tampered with. Goods have been stolen out of mail packages, including family tapes. As I mentioned in a personal explanation here today, a number of what we would describe as girlie magazines have also been removed. I understand that these are described as erotic magazines by South Africa and Namibia and therefore are against the law. Families who send those do so at their own risk but I have to question why the Australian Government has allowed our forces private mail to be tampered with by any authority en route to the men who are serving this country. Servicemen who are members of the First Division postal unit could have been sent to Namibia to deal with the mail at that end and we should have been able to arrange a service whereby the Australian soldiers' mail from their loved ones in Australia went straight through to the men in the field without interference by any other person or authority. As the shadow Minister I am concerned that I have not had a response from the responsible Minister as to how this has been allowed to happen and what action he has taken to see that the situation is improved.

This is the first time since World War II that our soldiers' mail has been censored. Not even in the most political days of Vietnam was the mail of our soldiers or their families censored. I also remind honourable senators that, apart from the phone, which is not always available or reliable and which costs quite a bit of money, mail is the only link between these men and their families. They need that link to retain the high morale which we expect of them in the field in representing Australia. I have written to Australia Post and to the Minister, Mr Simmons. I hope that the matter will be dealt with swiftly.

Whilst the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) tells us that these men will do Australians proud, his Government is providing no extra funds whatsoever for this contingent. My questioning of members of the Department of Defence at the Estimates committee hearings revealed that funding for the contingent will be in the order of $28m and will come from within the defence budget. No extra funding for this extra task will be provided by this Government at all. No real growth is planned for the defence budget for 1989-90. The answers to my questions in the Estimates committee were quite specific. No extra funding has been provided by the Government for this extra job. Funding will be needed at the rate of $28m. Inevitably that means that other things have to be dropped off. It means less training, and less minor and personal equipment. We already have a $28m shortfall in uniforms for the Army alone for the next two years. The Army does not know where it will find $28m simply to put its members in uniform. One wonders what the Government expects them to do. We have reached a stage where many servicemen provide their packs, compasses and boots. It looks as though soon they will be asked to provide their uniforms from either the opportunity shop or the disposals store. We have a very real problem in keeping these men in Iran-Iraq. As a nation we are very proud of them. I am sure the Government is truly proud of them; certainly the Opposition is. But when a government fails to provide the resources for them to do their job and fails to look after them and their families as effectively as it should while the men are away, I think that it should be condemned.

Recently we had another little example of the Government's mean spirit in regard to our soldiers when Senator Richardson, in answer to a question of mine, revealed that this Government was not even prepared to let the Australian Army have the honour of leading the Sinai force-which would have been at no cost to Australia. We could have had a lieutenant-general from Australia leading the multinational force in the Sinai. Instead that honour has gone to New Zealand which found that it had a general to spare. We have 44 generals and could not find one.

Finally I would like to draw attention to the amendments to the defence service home loans scheme, which is part of this package of legislation. Amongst other things, the upshot of the legislation is to tighten up the non-portability of loans taken out before 9 December 1987 by excluding eligible veterans who have already discharged their loans. The ridiculous situation therefore continues where there are two classes of home loan which have to be regulated. Those whose duty it is to move every two or three years are not entitled to take the home loan with them without ministerial permission. I hope in the committee stage of this legislation it can be explained to me under just what circumstances the Minister's permission will be either granted or withheld.

It is appropriate that I should draw attention to another con job-I hesitate to use the term, but I cannot think of an alternative one-that is being perpetrated on Australian servicemen who have joined the Defence Force since May 1985. Last month the Minister for defence science and Personnel, Mr Simmons, produced, like a rabbit out of a hat, a new defence service home loans scheme which is intended, one assumes, to make the post-May 1985 enlistees feel that they are loved and cherished by the Government. Instead, when we read the fine print, we find that, although the interest subsidy has been increased to cover a $40,000 loan, the interest payable will be at market rates less 40 per cent. At the time that the Minister announced the measure, the subsidised interest rate was already 9.6 per cent. As we all know only too well, that rate is moving inexorably upwards. Whereas servicemen used to be subject to a 6.85 per cent subsidised interest rate, the next generation of soldiers are already liable to pay at least 9.6 per cent and, as I said, that rate is going up.

The most serious criticism that I have of the new scheme is that it means that a serviceman will no longer have a subsidised interest rate for 25 years, which has been the case with the existing scheme. The new scheme means that the serviceman will get the subsidised interest rate only for the period in which he is serving in the Force, less six years that he had already served to become eligible. In other words, if a serviceman serves, as so many do these days, particularly other ranks, for only 10 years, he will receive a subsidised rate for only four years. To go from a 25-year subsidised interest rate to something like a four-year period is a seriously retrograde step. This is grossly unfair to the current generation of servicemen and it will clearly do nothing to encourage retention of personnel in the defence forces. Only somebody who did not understand the Defence Force could possibly imagine that that could be a retention measure. On the surface, it looks as though the longer one serves, the better it will be. But the current scheme is much better. That scheme is to be removed. Anybody who has joined the forces since May 1985 will no longer be eligible for the existing scheme. This poor shadow of a scheme is now being introduced as if it were something better, which clearly it is not.

In so many ways we are seeing that the Government is not prepared to look after our servicemen. By way of an aside, I wonder what the Westpac Banking Corporation has to say about the new scheme because I understood that it had contracted to take on board all those people who had become eligible to join the existing scheme but had not yet taken up their loans. On the basis of those calculations, Westpac paid a premium to take over the defence service home loan business. The Government has now announced that it intends that anybody who was in the defence forces prior to May 1985 will be able to opt out of the existing scheme and transfer across. I regard that as most unlikely because people will see that the new scheme is not as good as it at first appears. I would have thought that the Commonwealth could well be deemed to be in breach of its contract with Westpac by making that opportunity available to the pre-May 1985 enlistees.

Time prevents me from mentioning all the amendments. As I said earlier, some of those amendments are administrative in character. It was important that I single out the areas in which the Government should have given attention to soldiers and their entitlements. These matters are of great concern to the Opposition. The Government and the bureaucracy have shown inefficiency in many areas and ignorance of the needs of servicemen and ex-service men and women. What makes it worse for me is to see the Government constantly patting itself on the back for providing these repatriation benefits while, in reality, the courage and loyalty of our soldiers who are risking their lives overseas are being rewarded by a government with half measures, delayed benefits and bureaucratic bungling.
