SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a range of Bills which deal with social security and veterans affairs matters. As a member of the Government, I support the legislation. Before speaking to the details of the Bills, I wish to put them into an overall perspective in regard to this Government's policies and philosophies. The Hawke Labor Government came into office in 1983 at a time of deep recession in Australia. Under the previous Liberal Government, dole queues were swelling, inequality abounded and poverty was rife. The reality is that the Liberals in government did as much to reduce poverty in Australia as Burke and Wills did for orienteering. The Liberals had a pitiful record on helping families, assisting pensioners and social justice.

SPEECH.PARA: In seven years of coalition government, the number of children in pensioner and beneficiary families increased from 383,000 to over 800,000. The number of children depending on social welfare more than doubled. Only once in seven years of that Liberal Government was there an increase in family payments for children. Only once, in 1980-that was an election year-did payments for pensioners' children rise from $7.50 a week to $10 a week. We can conclude that, as a result, children were forced to bear the cost of the coalition's economic and social ineptitude. Over that seven-year period of the previous Liberal Government, child payments declined by more than 35 per cent; there was a 35 per cent cut in real terms in respect of payments to the children of pensioners and social welfare beneficiaries.

In marked contrast, the Hawke Government has increased payments for families every year that it has been in office. Payments in respect of the children of pensioners and beneficiaries have gone from $10 a week in 1983 when the Government was elected to a figure now of $24 a week for children under the age of 13-a 140 per cent increase. For older children-that is, children aged 13 to 15 years inclusive-the figure has gone from $10 a week when the Government was elected in 1983 to $31 a week. The social security and veterans affairs legislation that we are debating this afternoon will increase further those payments in respect of the children of pensioners and beneficiaries.

Importantly, the legislation will also increase payments for other families under the family allowance supplement scheme. Under this legislation, from July this year family allowance supplement payments and payments for children of pensioners and social welfare beneficiaries will rise from the present $31 a week to $34.10 a week for children aged 13, 14 and 15 years. That is the record of this Government-increases in payments for the children of pensioners and social welfare beneficiaries in every year the Government has been in office. That is our record and it is in marked contrast with the period under the Liberals when families were ignored. Under Labor, there have been increases in payments every year, whereas the coalition ignored families. Let us face it: the Liberals did as much for families in their period in office as Captain William Bligh did for industrial democracy. Under Labor, not only has the family allowance supplement risen but also the basic family allowance will rise by as much as 71 per cent in some cases. The family allowance will increase again from next month. It will increase to a figure of $9 a week for each of the first three children in a family. For larger families, the increase will be to $12 per week per child if there are four or more children in the family.

When the history books are written the Hawke Labor Government, based on these figures, will be seen as a government of vision, reform and compassion. The family allowance supplement scheme, when introduced in 1987, was a path breaking reform, a key part of Labor's attack on poverty. These Bills today mark further milestones in Labor's assistance for families in social reform and in the welfare of children.

The Bills will ensure that family payments-that is, the family allowance supplement for lower income families and the family allowance payment for most families-will increase every year from now on. For the first time ever all family payments will be indexed to the consumer price index each January, beginning next year. There will be automatic increases. They will apply not only to the family allowance but also to the disabled child allowance, the mother's and guardian's allowance, the sole parent rebate, the double orphan's pension and the multiple birth payment. All of those will face, for the first time ever, automatic cost of living rises from next January. Households with children no longer will have to rely on ad hoc or discretionary increases provided from time to time. Such families are guaranteed an adequate income for future years.

Family payments began, of course, with the introduction of child endowment in 1940 by the Menzies Government. But not once since that payment was introduced during the Second World War was there a cost of living rise to upgrade it for the higher cost of living in Australia. This Government has done it. It has brought in cost of living rises automatically every January in respect of family assistance payments. Also as a result of this package and as part of the April statement measures, the dependent spouse rebate will be increased. That will increase by about $170 per annum. That rebate against taxation will also be increased in line with cost of living rises, in line with inflation.

It is estimated that in my State of South Australia alone some 170,000 families will benefit from the increase in family payments. The payments will be made in respect of some 315,000 dependent children. I estimate that on a weekly basis the impact of this package alone-the family allowance increases and the rise in the family allowance supplement-will add of the order of $840,000 weekly to the purchasing power of South Australian families. In my State alone that figure accounts for an extra $43m going into households with dependent children.

I turn now to look at the national level and the impact these April statement measures will have on Australian families. I use the example of a family earning a gross income of $20,000 a year or about $380 per week with two dependent teenage children. A single income family in that position will pay no net taxation from July next. Such families will have zero income tax liabilities from the beginning of the next financial year. By net tax I mean their personal income tax liabilities less their family assistance payments. A single income family with two teenage children will have zero effective average tax rates if they are on around $20,000 per year. The taxation liability for such families will come to $2,117 after allowing for the increase in the dependent spouse rebate. The family on around $20,000 a year with two dependent children does not face a Medicare levy payment so the total tax bill calculated from the schedules is $2,117.

On the other hand, as a result of the increase in family assistance payments under this package, the family will receive a very significant boost in family payments. Again, a family with two dependent teenage children will get $936 per annum in family allowance payment. Such a family on $20,000 a year will also qualify for part of the family allowance supplement. That family will get $1,658 per annum, making a total family assistance of $2,594. That compares, of course, with a personal income tax liability that I have mentioned of $2,117.

As a result of the policies of the Hawke Labor Government such a single income family on $20,000 per annum with two dependent teenage children will in fact get back from the Government $477 more than it will pay to the Government in personal income tax. That can be likened to the concept of a negative income tax which has been discussed not only in this country by some social welfare groups in the past but also overseas. It has been discussed very widely in North America and parts of western Europe. In effect, from the beginning of July next Australia will have a negative income tax for a number of our families. Families earning below $20,000 per annum or $380 per week, with a single breadwinner, will have negative income tax. As a result of the April statement measures there will be very large improvements in the disposable income of many Australian families.

For example, a family in the same circumstances as I have mentioned but with two young children-that is, children who are not teenagers-will get from this package an extra $21.25 a week. That is the increase in, if you like, take home pay or disposable income after the reductions in personal income tax and the increases in both the family allowance supplement and the family allowance payments. An increase in disposable income of $21.25 per week is a significant figure. It comes out to over $1,100 per annum. Of course, that figure is a conservative one and a family with teenage children will get more.

The package itself highlights the Government's strategy very well-that is, to grant increases in the disposable income, the take home pay if you like, of Australian families by focusing on tax cuts and family assistance payments rather than encouraging workers to go out into the labour market to try to generate and obtain very large increases in money wages. As a matter of interest that $21.25 extra going to the family is equivalent to the breadwinner obtaining a wage rise of $36.15 per week. This is part of the Government's strategy to reduce cost pressure on industry, to reduce the need for large money wage rises, by giving tax cuts and boosting family assistance payments. As a result of employees not having to seek large wage rises, there are significant savings for industry. In turn, assistance is given to improving Australia's international competitiveness.

They are some of the measures taken by the Hawke Labor Government in the April statement. They are provided for in these Bills today, particularly the measures to boost family allowance payments and the family assistance supplement. That is in marked contrast with not only the rhetoric but also the actions of the Liberal Party when it was in government. In government, the Liberals showed that they were economically, politically and ideologically incapable of looking after Australian families. A decade ago the Liberals said that they would protect family incomes and they failed. Today this Labor Government is boosting family assistance enormously. It is against this record that the Government will continue to make further improvements to create a fairer, more just and more prosperous Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of the Bills in this package of legislation which the Senate is considering in this cognate debate, my remarks will be addressed to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. The first Bill deals basically in large measure with developments in the family package for families and children, increases in family allowance, simplification of that family allowance system, integrating the family allowance supplement payments, a range of indexation, and rebate rises in that whole area. I will return to that major area of the legislation shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: For the aged in our community the first Bill brings forward the pension indexation increases in three stages and increases the pension rebate so that the income test free area will become tax free, relieving the confusion and financial stress which has been in the system for a considerable time now. This simplification will mean that single pensioners will have to wait longer before they have that tax free status for their income test free area, whereas married pensioners will achieve that in the 1989-90 financial year. Single pensioners will not achieve it until the 1990-91 financial year. That is an unnecessary additional stress for single pensioners. The Australian Democrats find it difficult to work out why that should be the case.

The indexation catch-up is particularly welcome. The Senate will recall vividly no doubt, as it has been reminded many times since, that in the 1986 Budget the delay of six weeks was implemented along with a number of other stringent measures in the economic circumstances, with only the Australian Democrats opposed to it. Ever since then we have, along with pensioner groups, pushed for that delay to be redressed. On this occasion not only has the delay been redressed but also indexation has been brought further forward. This is a matter of justice for the group of aged in our community who, since 1986, have borne the brunt, particularly through this delay and through other stringencies which they and others in the community have had to meet in the face of economic circumstances. During that period the Democrats have been most concerned to express their view that many of the most disadvantaged in our community have had to bear an inordinate amount of that burden.

In making significant remarks on the family package elements of this legislation I would like to set the scene in which all of this is happening by drawing heavily on the submission entitled Federal Budget Priorities put out by the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) to the Australian Government. That submission came to us and the Government in April of this year. It sets the scene very well. With regard to the economic environment, the ACOSS submission points out that, as we all recognise, major economic difficulties are facing this country but due largely to severe cuts in Government spending the private sector now enjoys a greatly increased share of national resources. By a series of measures the private sector has had resources channelled to it and this often provides little or no benefit to the country. In many ways it can be shown to be causing severe economic damage. I will make some specific remarks on that later. The ACOSS submission states:

Grave misuse of resources has occurred through excesses in areas such as share and property speculation, currency trading, takeovers, asset-stripping and international tax avoidance. As a result, disappointingly little sustained progress has been made towards genuine economic restructuring which would improve our capacity to produce competitive exports, replace imports and create jobs. In addition, corporate debt levels have risen alarmingly, especially through excessive overseas borrowings.

At this point I wish to point out that at least the New South Wales Labor Party seems to have cottoned onto those issues which ACOSS outlines and which the Democrats have been pursuing for some time. I go on to the further point that is made in the submission in setting the economic scene. It states:

Two major causes of this misallocation of resources have been excessive business and financial deregulation and, despite courageous reforms, the continued bias of the tax system towards unproductive and speculative activities financed by massive borrowing.

I will interpolate there that this has occurred largely in the private sector from overseas transactions negatively geared to the disadvantage of the revenue of the Government which then has to cut its spending. That point is made further on in the submission where it states:
. . . it is important to bear in mind that Government spending has already been cut by about 15 per cent (that is-
in quantitative terms-

about $12 billion) over the last four years . . . It is now lower than at any other time for the last 15 years or so. No other Western country has even approached this size of expenditure reduction in recent years.

This needs to be put in the context of what the alternative government puts to us now via its new shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson. This is shown in all of his interviews which we have read since his appointment a relatively short time ago. An article in the Bulletin of 13 June states:

He says that in welfare, for example, he will be able to cut without hurting the needy. He says he will target welfare money better. He concedes that the Hawke Government has done this. When asked about the Government claim that it has cut as far as it can fairly go, he says that's a matter of judgment.

When we look at what this Government has already done in terms of cuts we find that the alternative situation looks rather gloomy. That does not give us a great deal of comfort. Calls for cuts extend beyond the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to what is clearly the constituency of the Liberal and National Opposition. They include calls for cuts from the Business Council of Australia, through Brian Loton, calls in its Budget submission by Mr Will Bailey of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd for a consumption tax which we understand would be greatly to the detriment of the low income people in our community and particularly welfare beneficiaries and a call backed up by Eric Mayer from National Mutual Life for an economic viewpoint which only augurs worse for those disadvantaged in our community.

The ACOSS economic picture goes on to point out that contrary to public myth-I would add Opposition party myth-the Government's total revenue from taxes and other sources is no higher than it was four years ago. As the earlier comments made demonstrate that is in large measure due to the sort of tax regime which the Government has implemented and to its failure to plug those gaps which have been exploited in the corporate sector. Although revenue from personal tax has increased ACOSS says that this has been offset by reductions in revenue from other sources. It is predicted in the Government's own Forward Estimates that expenditure in 1989-90 will be more than $3 billion lower than in 1988-89 when measured as a proportion of gross domestic product. That sort of economic environment is one which we must acknowledge. Within the package of legislation before us today at least some measures are being taken to pick up from where those cuts have been made or where increases which might have been expected in the normal course of events have not occurred.

In setting the social environment the ACOSS submission points out that middle income Australian families with dependent children have suffered a decline in living standards in the last four years while that process has been going on. It is that group which the family package embodied in this legislation helps. In its post-Budget documentation ACOSS acknowledges that with the headline on the front of its Impact magazine `A Big Help for Families' which clearly this package is. Let us not forget the families which have suffered over four years of restraint-restraint at their expense. In the social context ACOSS goes on to say:

Of even greater concern, however, is the increasing number of Australians who do not have secure employment and housing. They are largely the victims of the social and technological changes from which most other Australians have benefited substantially. They are the one who suffer most, for example, from rapidly increasing house prices and rentals and from the perceived need to restrain employment growth for fear of ``over-heating'' the economy.
The submission goes on to state:

It is sometimes alleged that low-income people have been protected from a decline in living standards over the last few years. The truth is that recent Budget cuts have reduced the income of many sole parents and young unemployed people by as much as 25-50 per cent. Indeed, a substantial number of people have been entirely deprived of income support by recent changes in the social security system.

Some of the people severely affected have been amongst the most vulnerable in our community. ACOSS mentions particularly many women who have been recently widowed or separated, many sole parent families, the long term unemployed, the young unemployed and disabled people. The submission further states:

Contrary to Government claims, even aged and invalid pensioners have suffered a decline in Government income support due to the additional 6 week delay in CPI indexation of pensions which was introduced several years ago.

As I have said, that is redressed in this package but we must remember that that deprivation has been going on since 1986. Whether or not that had to happen and whether or not we are now addressing the issue, the Democrats heartily agree with ACOSS that it is now more essential than ever that assistance be provided to those people who are in the greatest need. It is in that context that we address our remarks to this legislation.

We are told, and we accept, that the Government has met the benchmarks which it set for itself in terms of its child poverty promise. Along with ACOSS and other groups, we wish to comment on those benchmarks. Earlier in the debate, Senator Giles made some comments about the benchmarks. The Democrats acknowledge the setting of those benchmarks as important. However, we go further, as Senator Giles exhorted the Opposition to do, and say that they are not the ultimate solution. I do not imagine the Government believes they are either.

In a debate such as this, while we are saying that something is being achieved, we must also say what still needs to be achieved. The ACOSS view that the benchmarks need to be increased must be given some credence, especially in light of the fact that the Brotherhood of St Laurence has pointed out that the family package will help only some 30 per cent, at the outside, of those children who are living in poverty. Obviously, more needs to be done. The ACOSS benchmarks, which call for a $5 increase in the six to 12 years age group and for an $8 increase in the 13 to 15 years age group in order to account for family costs such as schooling, which vary across the age groups, need to be taken into consideration. A good deal more is yet to be done about the single parent families. It will take about an extra $15 per family to get them out of poverty in a general sense.

Senator Giles also referred to the process in which the Government has been engaged in the development of this package. The Democrats acknowledge that process, but within the context which I have mentioned. We acknowledge that to some degree the establishment of the benchmarks following the promise regarding child poverty is of itself a political benchmark. However, the Government must not rest on its laurels. We must look at those most disadvantaged in our community, those who need more assistance. I would like to focus on the three significant groups: sole parents, the unemployed-in particular the young unemployed-and the young homeless.

Sole parent families are families, but they have not done well out of this package. The Government has made a general attempt to help families, but I repeat that even the Brotherhood of St Laurence, which has said some very good things about what the Government is doing, has said that only 30 per cent of children living in poverty will be helped. It is of some concern that the Opposition barely pays lip service to the fact that sole parent families are families and therefore need consideration. Future Directions itself, with its picket fence politics, with its average family on the front cover, is a slap in the face for those sole parent families which are trying to struggle through. The image is wrong. We need to look at the facts: Sole parent families now constitute 14.6 per cent of all families, following a 75 per cent increase between 1974 and 1986. The majority of those single parent families result from marital separation, divorce or widowhood. The myth that a rash of young single girls have run out to get pregnant in order to get on the gravy train of benefits is just that-a cruel myth. That must be recognised. In June 1988 there were still nearly 450,000 children in sole parent families dependent on the social security pension. Even after the April statement, a single parent with one child was still $11.50 below the Henderson poverty line. It is important that sole parents speak for themselves. The Brotherhood of St Laurence in its document Promise the Children quoted some sole parent families. One reads:
I get the kids up late and give them a late breakfast so they don't need lunch. I can only afford two meals a day.
That parent has two pre-school children. A person who has two older children states:
The children only have gum boots. I hope it rains when school starts, then no one will know they don't have shoes.
I just hope that family lives in Sydney. Another quotation is from a sole parent speaking about her nine-year-old daughter:
At the moment my daughter is suffering from severe depression and she's on anti-depressants. It's due to my financial situation -She's taking my burden on her.
There are other stories. Another reads:
My daughter wanted to go on a school excursion. It cost $4.60. I said, ``stay home, it's too much money''.

This is the type of story that comes from these families, which, although they may have only one parent, are families nevertheless. Of course, in most cases those parents are women. The issue for sole parents is one of equivalence. I would like to put on the record some comments from the Council of Single Mothers and Their Children on this issue. The Council states:

Research into poverty has consistently shown that one-parent families are the family type most vulnerable to severe poverty . . . the Henderson poverty line, does not adequately take account of the income needs of one-parent families.
We are looking at another benchmark issue. The Council continues:
Social Security income support should be based on the equivalence of income needs between a sole parent household with one child and a married couple.
In other words, a household comprising two people. The Council goes on to state:
This equivalence measure was recognised by a wide range of community groups at the ACOSS National Consultation Congress on Income Support for families with children (December 1986) . . .

We need to begin to look at the equivalence issue if we are ever going to get the children from these families out of poverty. The equivalence issue has been recognised in some areas of the social security system, such as the income threshold for the payment of the family allowance supplement and the application of the Medicare levy. However, it is not recognised in other Government systems, particularly in the social security income support system and the taxation system. The Council states:

The Australian Institute of Family Studies has consistently indicated that one-parent families will remain the group most vulnerable to poverty unless specifically targeted measures are introduced. Within the present income support system, the mechanisms for adjusting sole parent pensions for adequacy is the Mother's/Guardian Allowance.

We welcome the indexation of the mother's/guardian's allowance-it does not come in until 1991-but we are concerned about the failure to increase the mother's/guardian's allowance because it is the only payment which distinguishes the female headed sole parent family, whose family costs are the same as other family costs, from other families. It may be that, with one adult and one child, food costs are marginally lower although, of course, it would depend on the age and appetite of the child. The costs of establishing the household, housing costs, transport costs and general family costs would not be significantly different, yet there is only a sole parent on a sole parent's benefit to meet those costs. In terms of the equivalence issue, a sole parent with one child after the April statement will get $160.25 a week, which is about 77 per cent of the married rate of pension. Therefore, if we accept that that equivalence rate is one that we should be shooting for, then we have some way to go. We believe that is perhaps the only way we can get that significant group of children out of poverty. The Council of Single Mothers and Their Children is calling for an increase to $20 in the coming Budget with a commitment to increase it further by 1991 to $30. It was also calling for half-yearly indexation. Well, annual indexation has been brought in, which will go some way towards that.

In the areas of sole parenting and equivalence we have to look at the specific problems that female parents in particular, and lone parents generally, have in exercising work force options. Being an only parent in a household is a job in itself. There is a great deal to do if one is going to get out of that situation. I know the Government has established some programs to get women into employment. Unfortunately all the messages that I have got thus far are that they are slow in starting, they are often not reaching particularly those women in isolated areas or those with low self-esteem, mainly because of the rather structured labour market orientation of most of the Government's programs in this area, and also that the problems with child-care options are still in the system. This is difficult for all sole parents, but particularly for female sole parents.

The question of community attitudes to sole parents is one that the people in this place should address. I am most concerned about the lack of discussion on that and the image which is portrayed by the Opposition, which gives sole parents the feeling that there is not a great deal of sympathy from the political end towards understanding the difficulty where community attitudes are significantly against such a group, which bears a very difficult burden.

Finally, I want to address the treatment of sole parents by the Department of Social Security. I, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, have previously protested against the draconian measures which are available to and are used by the Department all too often, especially when they are directed towards sole parents, and particularly females. Some of these are generated by the general view of the Government that we need to save money. Nobody wants to see fraud perpetrated, but we must ask what some of the savings that we assume we are making will cost. There has been a rash of very inhumane gaolings of women, some of them with very small children, and a large number of prosecutions. But when we stack up questions of fraud against questions of survival, the first question we should ask ourselves is: Why do people who have children to raise find it necessary to misrepresent their situation?

I am pleased to say that the question of debt recovery is being addressed by a Senate committee and I look forward to its results. I want to put on the record a `special of the month' that has been offered by the Department of Social Security to some of these women. A constituent brought a copy to me. It states, `For the month of June we are offering you a chance to finalise your debt in one payment'. This letter was written to a woman who owes the Department some $4,000 in overpayments as a result of her misrepresenting her situation. She is told, in this special offer, that if she can find $2,000 before 30 June, she will save almost $500. I think this is a fairly cruel approach by the Department. If this woman had $2,000, I am absolutely certain she would not have been in the position of allowing herself to be overpaid $4,000. If she had access to that sort of money, she would not have had to take the desperate measure which most law-abiding citizens in our community would not want to take, and that is to engage in at least a form of fraud, even for survival. But for the Department then to offer this monthly special and to say, `Hurry, hurry, if you do not get in before 30 June, then you will lose the chance to save $500', I think is quite cruel. It is also discriminatory against those who do not have access to $2,000. Perhaps she will beg around her family, her neighbours or somebody else and drag the money together, but those who cannot do even that are, of course, even further discriminated against.

The other group about whom we are most concerned are the unemployed. I have said often in this place that the Democrats find it abhorrent that there seems to be a general feeling out there, particularly in the political and economic communities, that we cannot afford to lower our unemployment level too much because we have this overheating economy. Articles such as that in the Australian Financial Review on Friday, 9 June, express some concern about the continued buoyancy in the labour market driven by a strong increase in women's employment and part-time jobs, which of course are better for women and which are more available to young people because often they are relatively unskilled. The pressure on the housing industry being perpetrated by the high interest rates lends strength to the arm of those who do not want to see unemployment go down and the pressure on the economy go up any more, and who want to see ordinary people put the lid on the economy. Other than people in the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party, who have seen the light, they do not want to see our international potentates have to pull in their overseas borrowing, they do not want to put a tax on luxury imports, they do not want to give incentives for savings and they do not want to give tax deductability for home buyers-that is, not if they want to live in their own homes. We are saying that the ordinary people ought to be given more consideration.

The young unemployed and, in particular, those who through their unemployment or as a result of trying to find employment, find themselves homeless are a particular group we are concerned for. This concern has been consistent as it is more than a year since I first moved amendments to improve access to the young homeless allowance. We will be doing that again in the committee stage of this legislation, because we believe now, as we did then, and as Commissioner Burdekin of the Human Rights Commission believes, that we have a commitment to support the young people in our community under the Declaration of the Rights of the Child. For that reason we are picking up three of the recommendations of the Burdekin report with reference to the young homeless allowance in an attempt once more to get this Parliament to give some leadership in this area. We will be very interested in the response of the other parties in this place to that.

In the last few minutes at my disposal I will outline the nature of the amendments which we will be moving. We will be moving an amendment to the first Bill for six-monthly indexation. As I have said, that is something which the Council of Single Mothers and Their Children has asked for and we certainly believe that that is the least that can be done. We welcome annual indexation. It is way overdue, and we believe that six-monthly indexation ought to be possible. The fact that there is annual indexation does not necessarily give great cause for congratulation when there is quarterly indexation of public funding for political parties. We will also be moving amendments to encourage the Department to improve its 008 telephone facilities and to waive the waiting period in the second Bill where annual leave payments have been used. I now move my amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, which states:
At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate, noting that:
(a) rental assistance payments take no account of the wide variations in the costs of rent around Australia and within individual States; and
(b) beneficiaries have limited discretion in the matter of where they live;

expresses its concern about the unfair implications of the present arrangements and urges the government to implement a rent assistance system which would provide payments in relation to the `market' rent in the area in which a beneficiary lives''.

As long as the Auditor-General can keep his eye on it, he can make sure that it stays within bounds. I do not think that anybody could argue about the restitution provisions for the victims of Nazi persecution nor could he argue about the adjustments to the entitlements for service pension beneficiaries.

The section that concerns the veterans in the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill is the restoration of some of the benefits that veterans have lost over the years. Honourable senators will remember that benefits were taken from veterans, widows and other dependants in 10 areas. Dental treatment was restricted, allowances for travel for treatment of war caused disabilities were reduced and access to pharmaceutical benefits was reduced. Part of this Bill in some way makes up for that. We welcome the indexation that has been granted and the speed with which the Government passed to veterans, war widows and people in other categories the consumer price index increases.

This Bill also restores the 2 per cent Defence Force retirement benefit, which was cut out some time ago. To my mind cutting out that 2 per cent was clearly a breach of contract by the Government. If the veterans could have afforded to take the Government to court, I am sure that they would have won. This is in the same category as the case decided yesterday. The Government had cut back the pharmaceutical benefits prescription fee by 10c a prescription. This caused a great loss to pharmacists in Australia. Yesterday the court put down a decision and the Government was found to be in breach. This was similarly the case with pathology services. The Government unreasonably cut back on the provision of pathology services and the pathologists took the Government to court. They won their case too. Had the veterans taken the Government to court on the grounds of breach of contract for cutting that 2 per cent I am sure that they would have won.

The provisions in the social security legislation Bills are really a result of the 12 April economic statement. The social security Bill covers family payments, pension and benefit indexation, child disability allowances and benefits for double orphan pension recipients. Some time ago the Government introduced its policy statement entitled Towards a Fairer Australia, which was full of rhetoric but was left wanting until now when we are debating the substantiation of the Government's actions.

To assess how families stand in Australia today it is necessary to look at some figures. The disposable weekly income of a family with a dependent spouse and two children is much lower now than in 1977. Indeed, a double income family would need $71 a week to make up the difference and a single income family would need $56 a week. The tax cuts announced on 12 April, which will not take effect until next month, will be eroded not only by inflation but also by the effects of bracket creep putting people in higher tax brackets, not to mention the other inescapable increases such as sales tax, which has increased almost 150 per cent and counting under this Government. The Medicare levy, which has been increased, and other adjustments to the dependent spouse rebate and the concessional rebate will also increase the amount of tax families have to meet.

All these changes are on top of the capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax and a broadening of indirect taxes which extend their effect right to low income families because everybody has to pay them. The Labor policy may be towards a fairer Australia but Australia as a society is a lot less fairer than it has ever been and the Government's policies are increasing the polarity between the rich and the poor and the disadvantaged. The number of people considered to be below the poverty level is increasing. Today 2.6 million households-that is, one in every eight-are living below the poverty level. Included in this number are 800,000 children. Child poverty is now a major issue in Australia despite the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) two years ago that no child would be living in poverty after 1990. Child homelessness has become a social blight and exposes these children to crime, drugs, acquired immune deficiency syndrome and sexual abuse. There is a huge feature page on youth homelessness in Brisbane in today's Courier-Mail.

The area of housing presents a desolate picture and housing poverty is concentrated amongst families with dependent children. The private rental market is the most severely affected. Around Australia there are almost 200,000 families on public housing waiting lists. The Government offer of small increases in rental subsidies is not an adequate response to this problem. Housing costs vary from place to place and should be addressed on this basis despite the constitutional problems involved. For example, housing costs on Thursday Island are a lot different from housing costs in Sydney.

The high interest rate policy pursued by this Government has increased average mortgage repayments by at least $500 a month since 1983 and the rates have now gone from 13 per cent to 18 or 19 per cent, which averages about $2,000 more than nine months ago. The Government has not recognised the correlation between poverty and unemployment. As a proportion of the unemployed, those with children have increased from 37 per cent to 46 per cent in the last six years. But the greatest proportional increase in unemployment rates has been for families with three or more children. The duration of unemployment for people seeking full time work is now 47 weeks. That is an increase of 23 per cent since March 1983. The Government claims to have created 1.2 million new jobs. This figure takes no account of the fact that Australia needs at least 60,000 new jobs a year to keep up with population growth and school leavers. To precipitate further family breakdown, wives have been forced to go out to work in order to make ends meet.

It is obvious that families bear the brunt of unemployment. Nearly 40 per cent of long term unemployment beneficiaries have three or more children. In addition, teenage unemployment is still over 20 per cent and even worse in some areas. The Government policy mix is out of kilter with the problems it has created, as shown by the growing number of people who are living in caravan parks around Australia.

I will not go on for long because we will adjourn early tonight. I just wanted to make those points. One of the amendments to be introduced is for the provision of 008 numbers so that people can contact their government departments. I welcome that initiative. It is one which we brought in last week with the telecommunications Bills, but it was rejected because the Australian Democrats did not want to see it go into that legislation. So now an amendment is to be moved every time one of these Bills comes up. I suppose they want to claim credit for it. City people are able to ring the whole gamut of government departments for the cost of a local call but country people, who should have similar access to departments, do not have that advantage. With a department such as the Department of Social Security, which is a real growth area with more and more people needing to contact it, this initiative will be useful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am almost speechless after Senator Sheil's contribution. I do not think that I have heard such a gathering of myth and legend in one speech in a long time. I suggest that Senator Sheil read other people's contributions to this debate and check all of his claims for accuracy. I support this package of legislation-the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill and the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill. In particular I will address my remarks to the comments about the commitment to families and the changes from which families will benefit as a result of the legislation being passed by this place. Apparently Senator Sheil does not take any notice of what bodies such as the Brotherhood of St Laurence and the Australian Institute of Family Studies have to say. Before he leaves the chamber I will remind him that the Brotherhood of St Laurence stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We congratulate the Federal Government on its work on child poverty, which represents a historic breakthrough in the national attack on child poverty. The Federal Government has now built a solid foundation of income security for Australian families.

Senator Sheil should attend to that statement because what he has said is wrong and takes no account of the facts of the legislation, let alone the changes that have been implemented by the Government since it has been in office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the Courier-Mail.

—If Senator Sheil wants to stick with the speech that was worked out for him by somebody else, which has been repeated ad nauseam in this place and which takes no account of changes to figures and so on, he can continue to do that but he will not persuade me, or anybody else on this side, or many Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, in introducing the legislation, has achieved benchmarks. It has written them into legislation; they are enshrined there. While I did not hear all that Senator Giles said, I am absolutely sure that she covered those matters most comprehensively. I would only endorse the remarks of my colleagues Senator Giles and Senator Maguire as to the details. That establishment of benchmarks is very important. The Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty recommended benchmarks. In fact, the Government has introduced benchmarks that exceed Henderson's proposals. I do not believe we can overlook the importance of that fantastic contribution. Not only are those benchmarks now written into legislation and established for all time but they are also indexed so they can never be eroded to less than their current level unless, of course, the Opposition gets into government and develops some of the peculiar proposals of Dr Hewson, the shadow Treasurer. I will come to that later.

This is a very significant piece of legislation. If I have one minor complaint it is that we are being asked to address it, speak to it and debate it in this place with the session almost over and not sufficient time to acknowledge and spell out the importance of this matter. It is an absolutely fantastic and significant piece of legislation. It puts those benchmarks for children into legislation. It indexes the payments so those benchmarks can never be eroded. The attack on child poverty to which this Government has been committed, is committed and will continue to be committed is unmatched and is something of which we can be totally unashamed. If any criticism could be offered to the Government-and it is a mean one-it is perhaps that more might have to be done in days ahead. But to suggest that what we have done in the legislation does not address child poverty is not only specious but also little-minded and, in the end, wrong. The Institute of Family Studies, describing Labor's commitment to these standards of adequacy, stated:
Probably most significant of all, the linking of the rates of payment for FAS-
that is, the family allowance supplement-
to those for the married rate of pension, along with the widening of eligibility for low income working families, effectively produces a guaranteed minimum income scheme for all children.

We know that for younger children the payments have been established and increased from $22.25 to $33 and, for 13, 14 and 15-year-olds, from $22.25 to $43.10. The payments constitute 15.3 per cent and 20 per cent of married rate pension respectively. That is the absolutely fantastic core of the legislation. It is vital, significant legislation. Senator Sheil might note this figure: more than 530,000 families with 1.1 million children will benefit. He might go away and work out whether the figures which he muttered in a speech written many years ago are accurate.

As I have said before, the standards exceed those recommended by Professor Henderson in his Commission of Inquiry into Poverty. He recommended 12 per cent, 15 per cent and 18 per cent in terms of one, two and three children. The Government has gone to 15.3 per cent and 20 per cent. The important thing is that the payments, particularly the family allowance, not only have been increased but also are to be indexed. With the family allowance supplement, automatic adjustment has been arranged to make sure that the standards of child payment of 15 and 20 per cent of those benchmarks will be maintained; indeed, with the arrangements, they may sometimes be exceeded.

I will run over these latest commitments and put them against the Government's commitment to children. From 1983 right through there has been an increase for children in low income families every year-in 1983, from $10 to $12; in 1984, $12 to $14; in 1985, $14 to $16; in 1986, $16 to $17; and in 1987, $17 to $22 for younger children and $17 to $28 for 13, 14 and 15-year-olds. In 1988, it went from $22 to $24 and $28 to $31 respectively. In 1989, the top payment-recognising, as the Government always has, that teenagers cost more than youngsters-has gone to $34.10 per child for 13-, 14- and 15-year-olds.

Those increases have been associated with the increase in the family allowance, which has gone from $5.25 to $9 per week for the first child, together with the indexation of family allowance levels. Currently, a family's income would have to be about $53,000-plus before it would be ineligible for family allowance for the first child. We must remember that for all subsequent children that family's income increases by $2,500 per child. That means that the prospect of families with more than one child, particularly large families, being able to enjoy family allowance and now the increased family allowance is very much higher.

The Government has addressed, first of all, the problem of income support and child support for families on the lowest income scale. With this package it has extended that, along with the tax cuts, to encompass families in the middle income range. That is a quite remarkable achievement, particularly in times of economic stringency. It also acknowledges the contribution Australian wage and salary earners have made. I would not endorse much of what Senator Powell said, but I would endorse her comment that pensioners, by having their pension increase deferred by six weeks, have also contributed. That must be acknowledged. While nobody is happy at losing income, many of the pensioners to whom I spoke were not unhappy to do their bit to contribute to this country's recovery. In fact, that has happened.

Some of the benefits which Senator Powell sees today and supports in the legislation are due entirely to the Government's economic management over the past three years, particularly in 1986-87, when this country was faced with great challenges. Those people who tightened their belts and contributed to the recovery during that tough time now stand to be acknowledged for that contribution. They will appreciate the increased benefits through tax cuts and family payments. In the short time that we have allotted to us, I cannot go through the details of benefits in this package. But I suggest that Senator Powell might look more comprehensively at the benefits for sole parents. We can always find some small part to complain about, but the Government has been very aware of the need to assist sole parents.

The most important way in which we can assist any pensioner-excluding age pensioners-is to provide the opportunity for training, education and employment. Nobody wants, or looks forward to, a life of perpetual poverty on a pension. A pension provides, if not perpetual poverty, a restricted income, and the prospects and opportunities for a family are consequently reduced. In particular, the Government has targeted supporting parents by way of the jobs, education and training program. The three relevant departments are combining to provide opportunities and assistance for sole parents to get back into training and education, and are addressing the necessary consequence of adequate child-care.

This package cannot be seen as assistance for families separate from all the other things the Government has been doing since it came to office. It has to be taken in association with the changes in the health area with the introduction of Medicare and the exemption from the Medicare payment for a couple with an income of just over $16,000, with the allowable income increasing by over $2,300 per child. Single persons earning an income of below $9,500 are also exempt. The Medicare payment provides a guarantee of health coverage for people without their having either to take the risk of having no insurance or to pay much more for private insurance than they would for the Medicare levy. Thousands of Australians have exercised their option under Medicare and appreciate that that covers their needs. That has been of benefit to families too, as have the Government's education policies and our child care policies, which are absolutely unmatched. All of the provisions introduced by this Government since it came to office in 1983 have been unmatched.

Much of the early work was to redress the disasters left by seven years of Fraser-the huge unemployment levels we faced, the dreadful economic downturn and the failure of payments to assist adequately families and children. The Opposition's saying that it has put families on the agenda and shamelessly suggesting that we are not doing enough demonstrates considerable gall. I do not understand how Opposition members can do that. I believe Senator Bishop started her remarks today by saying that it was the Opposition that put families on the agenda, in its Future Directions document. The kindest thing I could do is chuckle; the worst is something more than that. That is a farce! Families have been on the agenda of this Government in its campaigning and in its policies since before it came to office. It has been part of the thinking, planning and development of this Government all the while. I do not dare think that it has reached its peak; I would like to see it progressing ever onwards and upwards. The commitment to the family which is very much the focus of this legislation addresses the promise and the challenge to which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) committed this Government; concern to assist children out of poverty.

I would like to turn to what the Opposition has to say in this area. There is lot of evidence about the outcome of the former Government's policies. Senator Maguire may have spelled out some such evidence that suggested that, when in government, the Opposition's policies were disastrous for families. It made one increase in payments for families in its seven years in office, as I recollect the data, but it did even less to assist families by way of payments for children. It also left this country with massive unemployment when it went out of office. I note that Senator Sheil thinks that the creation of 1.2 million jobs-he is not quite right; it is now 1.4 million-is not of much benefit to families. I do not know how he can sustain that argument. This has been one of the fantastic achievements of this Government. What does the Opposition tell us it will do if it ever gets into government again? Senator Bishop says that Future Directions has put the family on its agenda. As I have said in other places, if we read that document, provided one talks about a nuclear family, with two children being reared behind a picket fence with roses over the gate, one could probably describe such people as a family. Otherwise families do not exist in the document.

Another important area for families is child-care. The Future Directions document devotes less than two column inches to it. The document itself is of no comfort to us. The Opposition made five promises in that document, which were reduced to three by the time Mr Howard spoke about it. So the promises made in the document were cut by the Opposition before it even spelt out exactly what they meant. Dr Hewson is now promising what he would do when the Opposition gets into government. He is in a particularly interesting situation to set out details of such promises. The Opposition seems to argue, as does Dr Hewson, that it will cut spending; it will expand spending; and it is not quite clear in what areas it will do either of those.

It is interesting that one of the principal objections raised in this place by the Opposition is that the Government often does things for cost containment, as though this is a blot on and a slur against the Government. The Opposition seems to argue that what we should do is expend more, but it then says that it plans to cut expenditure. Dr Hewson is better than most because he has said that he will cut expenditure in the areas of social security, health and education. That is very challenging, particularly if we consider what might be of advantage to families in those areas. How does Dr Hewson propose that families will benefit from cuts in social security, health and education? If he has any idea of what he means by that, he has not made it clear to people on this side of the chamber or in the other place. Mr Howe, in the other place and in a number of public forums, has challenged Dr Hewson to say what exactly he is planning to do. The best response we can get from Dr Hewson is that perhaps the Government could target more accurately. We have been given some strange figures. We have been told that if we spend $26 billion on all the people in Australia, by dividing, multiplying and parsing, we will eventually come up with a figure for the needy of $26,000-or maybe he meant $13,000 per head. This is outrageous.

I do not think Dr Hewson gives any comfort by those comments. He indicates that he does not know what is happening in the social security area. He says that he will cut expenditure, that he will tighten things down. But he does not say by how much. He does not acknowledge that that is exactly what the Government has achieved dramatically to this point. Since 1983 social security outlays have fallen from 6.9 per cent of gross domestic product to 6.2 per cent in 1987-88, with a projected 6 per cent this year. What is Dr Hewson's offer? Is he offering 5 per cent? How does he plan to do that? He seems to suggest that this Government is extravagant in its expenditure. He does not seem to appreciate that social security outlays have fallen under this Government, while payments to people who are eligible have increased dramatically, as this package of legislation indicates.

The other thing he does not seem to appreciate is that since 1983 the proportion of pensioner beneficiaries has fallen from 41.9 per hundred people in the labour force to 35.9 per hundred in June 1988. He does not appreciate that there used to be 600,000 people registered for unemployment benefit; that has fallen to 400,000. The Government would say that is still too high and we are working to reduce it. But it is a remarkable drop and it is a figure that Senator Sheil has not mastered. People gaining work represents a double benefit for government. No longer do those people have to survive on the unemployment benefit-which represents a saving in expenditure for government-but also they are in the work force and thus they are paying tax and contributing to revenue.

I would have thought that one could take no comfort at all from the Opposition's comments, let alone those of the shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson. He does not understand what is happening in the Department of Social Security-to take just one area that he has targeted and made wild comments about. Generally, his only proposals are for cuts in social security. Perhaps Senator Walsh is sharper than I, but I certainly think his comments in the Sydney Morning Herald of 29 May 1989 should give Dr Hewson some reason to pause. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has suggested that Dr Hewson, because of his lifestyle, is hardly likely to have any appreciation of which people are genuinely needy. Dr Hewson has also indicated that he does not understand what `targeting' means. He certainly does not appreciate how much this Government has been able to achieve. While reducing the number of people on pensions and benefits, it has been able to increase the payments to all those who are eligible. He also does not appreciate the restraint and reduction within the Department of Social Security, nor does he seem to appreciate the extraordinary contribution of the people in that Department.

From time to time we might find one person who, one way or another, has had a less than courteous response when attending one of the Social Security offices around the country. I would certainly be pleased to place on the record that the majority of people in the Department have worked flat out and marvellously over the last six years to cope with and address the number of changes that have been required of them by government and to make those changes clear to the people who seek assistance when they come into Social Security offices. There has never been a period in the history of the Department of Social Security when as many changes have had to be mastered and dealt with. I certainly commend the Department and, if not all, the majority of people who provide assistance to thousands of people in the community who benefit.

In summary, the Brotherhood of St Laurence has established a high credibility in commenting on matters of poverty in this community. That organisation has commended the Government for establishing its benchmarks. The Institute of Family Studies has said how comprehensive and how effective the proposals in this legislation are. Those proposals represent a quite splendid and principled commitment to the alleviation of poverty. This commitment has never been established by any government; it certainly has not been addressed as effectively and as splendidly as it is in this legislation. We have, by way of the Opposition's comments, nothing more than a suggestion that perhaps Future Directions is the way to go because it mentions the family. This Government was concerned about the family prior to being elected to office in 1983. It has addressed the needs of the family in a comprehensive way by providing all sorts of services in its legislation. The family is not a novelty for the Government; it is not something new; it is part of this Government's commitment. If people want to see proof of that, they should read this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The quickest way for me to close this debate would be to endorse most of what Senator Crowley has said in response to Opposition speakers. I anticipate that much of what is in contention will be discussed in the committee stage, so it does not need to be addressed now. Briefly, at this stage I need to make a number of points in response to some of the basic points made by some Opposition speakers during the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point that needs to be tackled is the one made by Senator Bishop, Senator Powell and Senator Sheil. They claimed that the family package has helped only 30 per cent of children who were previously living in poverty. Senator Crowley made the point rather convincingly that their speeches must have been written a few years ago. That figure of 30 per cent applies to those children who were lifted above the Henderson poverty line by the first family package in 1987. Since then there was an increase in 1988 and this legislation encompasses a further big increase. When making assessments such as this, one needs to point to the relevance of the Henderson poverty line-a relevance that has been disputed not only by the Government but also continually by official Opposition spokespersons.

The second point that needs to be addressed-I think it was made by Senator Bishop-is the claim that Australia ranks second worst in the world in terms of the number of people living in poverty. It should be recognised that the figure that was quoted came from a Luxembourg study on income distributions that was conducted in 1981. That study spelt out the situation in 1981. Without going into a massive political debate, people should recognise that, in that period, another party was in government.

In this brief summary, the third point that needs to be tackled is the claim that somewhere in the vicinity of 800,000 children are now living in poverty. We know where that figure came from as well. We would have expected some degree of honesty in this respect. The Government figure relates to the number of children living in poverty before the introduction of the family package. This fact has been widely acknowledged-Senator Crowley also referred to this in her contribution-by organisations such as the Brotherhood of St Laurence and other independent organisations. The magnitude of the Government's performance in this area can be measured by the fact that over 530,000 low income families and 1.1 million children are encompassed by the Government's plans. I have dealt only with the family package. When we take into account the fact that over one million Australians have found employment in the course of this Government's period of office and recognise that employment security is the most basic part of income security, we can then see the massive inroads that this Government has made in this area.

Let me signal the Government's position in relation to some of the amendments that will be moved later today. I anticipate that Senator Powell will move an amended amendment in respect of the 008 national line. I also anticipate that the Government will be able to accept that amendment. Basically, the Department of Veterans' Affairs already has a national 008 line for its clients. The Department of Social Security has an extensive and very proud record of use of its 008 lines. But, as we discovered in the debate last week on telecommunications legislation, the technology involved with 008 lines is moving very quickly. It may well be that an appropriate strategy can be linked to the changing technology which will give 008 lines the flexibility to lock into a number of either national, State or regional lines. Accordingly, the amendment which will be moved by the Australian Democrats will be acceptable to us. However, it should be stated that all of the other Democrat amendments that will be moved during the committee stage will be opposed by the Government.

The Government will oppose the amendment moved by the Democrats to the motion for the second reading which refers to rental assistance payments and so on. That amendment does not take into account the Government's announcements in the last Budget which have led to a major restructuring of the rent assistance program. The Government has encompassed a system whereby payments can be linked to market rental. Even though the Democrats' approach has a superficial attractiveness, we need only look at a similar system to that of the Democrats which operated in the United Kingdom to see the inherent dangers in their proposal. We would finish up with a system under which market rents would increase. All sorts of discriminatory flow-ons would result because of the lack of a well thought out system.

The Government has targeted rental assistance. There will be add-ons for children in recognition of the fact that families with children have high housing costs. The Government will take into account the cost of housing through the rent threshold. This measure was also adjusted by the Government yesterday. As I have said, we reject the Democrats' amendment.
Amendment negatived.

As I said at the second reading stage, we acknowledge the improvement in the indexation situation. One of the most significant means of causing a decline in social security benefits over the years has been the lack of indexation. Therefore, any indexation is important. However, it seems to the Australian Democrats that half-yearly indexation would be much more effective. All of these benefits are given to areas of need. They are payments which in large measure still are inadequate, particularly in the context of a community in which it is quite obvious that the rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer.

We do not accept the Government's argument that what we are proposing cannot be afforded-not when we see the avenues that are still open to this Government to increase its revenue from the corporate sector. It could address the problems of our current account deficit by tackling the issues of negative gearing on foreign borrowings and limiting imports of foreign products where they are not part of the productive development of our economy. The Government has failed to implement those measures; therefore we feel that it does not have firm ground on which to object to moves as we propose, which will give some further minimal advantage to the most disadvantaged in our community.

I stress that, for a chamber comprising politicians to have passed legislation which indexes on a quarterly basis the funding for parliamentary elections and then to turn around and fail to index on a half-yearly basis the mother's/guardian's allowance, the family allowance, the family allowance supplement and orphan's pensions, has, at the very least, a selfish, if not nasty, ring to it. I have moved these amendments on behalf of the Australian Democrats in the interests of fairness and equity while at the same time acknowledging that indexation is with us through this legislation but in what we consider to be an inadequate form. I also remind the chamber that quarterly indexation has been the policy of the Australian Democrats for the past 12 years, and it will continue. Perhaps here we are suggesting something like a halfway house which will go to the advantage of the disadvantaged in our community.

The amendment takes up three of the recommendations of the report, Our Homeless Children, by the National Inquiry into Homeless Children by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, known as the Burdekin report. As I said in my second reading stage speech, briefly the question of access to the young homeless allowance has been a matter of concern to the Australian Democrats consistently for some time. The issue has been addressed quite directly in these recommendations of the Burdekin report. It seems to us, as it does to Mr Burdekin obviously, that one of the key areas in which we need to move and move quickly is that of income support for our young people. Not all people who would qualify for the young homeless allowance are necessarily homeless under the same definition as the homeless children who have gained much more publicity and attention since the release of this report. They are homeless, however, in the sense that they are not living in a family home. We are saying that adequate income support must be made available.

Almost two years ago in Victoria, groups of youth workers and others concerned about this issue came to Canberra. It was interesting that Senator Cooney, Senator Patterson and I attempted to have a press conference to support the proposals of this group to make access to the young homeless allowance easier and less restrictive. We were talking about access, not so much about adequacy, although that is also a problem. I want that to be on the record, after the last exchange. The media were not at all interested because members of all political parties across the spectrum were pursuing a social justice issue. It was not a media event at all. I am aware that people around the chamber are concerned about this issue, as are people throughout the community.

The amendment is slightly different from those we moved last year; if anything it is more conservative, but it picks up the three recommendations of the Burdekin report. The allowance should be available equally to children under 16 and young people 16 and 17 years of age. The Burdekin inquiry and other forums drew to our attention the fact that many young people under the age of 16 are homeless and income support is essential to them. Therefore, we do not believe that they should be excluded. The other recommendation picked up in this amendment is that during the assessment period, which is essential for the assessment of individuals applying for the allowance, a special benefit should be paid so that income support is available during that process. One of the problems with the young homeless allowance has been the tortuous nature of the assessment and therefore the long period during which there is no income support.

We also picked up the further recommendation that the criteria for homelessness should be extended to include a test of independence. The test recommended by Burdekin and picked up by us in our amendment is that a person who has lived away from home for three months should qualify for the allowance without the need to meet the other criteria which exist with regard to that allowance. Those other criteria relate to various proofs of homelessness, various statements from parents and so on. In our proposed new subsection 8b we are saying that a benefit should be paid in the assessment period but in proposed new subsection 8c we say that the application would have to be suitably supported by a youth worker or a social worker from the Department. We are not saying that any young person should just be able to go up and get a benefit. We believe an application would need to be supported by appropriate people.

The amendment is more conservative than those we moved last time because last time we were trying to do away with the longer waiting period. Nevertheless, if this Parliament is to show any leadership in this area, it should move in the area of income support for a significant group of young people but, perhaps more importantly, a very deserving and needy group of young people. We are as aware as anybody that it is not just a matter of income support. Many measures are needed, not the least of which are family supports because of the stresses on families which often lead to this homelessness. However, this is one area in which we can move. The Victorian Government is showing its credentials in announcing an $11 1/2m package. It is not a perfect situation. It is over a four-year period and therefore somewhat thin, but at least, should we move on this, we could say there would be support elsewhere at different levels of government and certainly in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government also opposes the amendments, for two sets of reasons: the first general and the second more specific. What we have in process is the development of a social justice strategy for young people which will be announced in the Budget context. We also have in process a working party of Commonwealth and State officials working on the inquiry into homeless children. That particular working party is reporting today at a meeting of Commonwealth and State welfare Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: In essence the major issues involved are not just the levels of income support payments concentrated upon by Brian Burdekin in chapter 14 of his report, Our Homeless Children, but a whole range of interrelated issues such as promoting participation by young people in worthwhile activities, reinforcing parental responsibility and so on. There are also questions about Federal and State responsibilities and roles, as well as community roles, all of which have been highlighted by organisations such as the Brotherhood of St Laurence. These issues are very much at the forefront of the Government's considerations in developing its social justice strategy for youth.

Specific problems-I instance just two-arise out of the amendments from the Australian Democrats. Under the proposed subsection (8a), for instance, every child who qualified as homeless would automatically be entitled to young homeless allowance regardless of age and regardless of work or activity test requirements. One could have 10-year-olds who were not living at home being paid an allowance by the Commonwealth.

It is very much a broad amendment which may have as its motivation the right sentiment but it has particular problems in implementation. Proposed subsections (8b) and (8c), for instance, create a completely new discretionary benefit with not one iota of criterion of eligibility for the benefit. Very briefly, the proposal would cause the Government two significant problems. As I said, there are no criteria for eligibility. Under this Democrats' amendment a social worker could properly determine to pay the benefit to a young person who lived at home. The proposal would give unlimited discretion to any social worker employed in the Public Service. That of course would have all sorts of problems in terms of appeals, the roles of social workers, the discretionary powers of social workers and so on.

It is very much a general amendment, the bottom line of which-it may be that the Australian Democrats have not assessed it closely enough to work this out-is, for example, that proposed subsections (8b) and (8c) would permit payment of a homeless allowance to a young person who was living in a house supplied by his or her parents and provided with regular maintenance by his or her parents. That could be done on the recommendation of a social worker and in the circumstances in which that child was away for three months and asserted independence. In essence we have problems with the amendment. We are concerned about developing a cohesive, coherent, broad response to the problem. We warn the Senate that the amendment, as now framed, would cause unforeseen problems that have not been foreseen by those who moved it.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund-WorkCare

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:
